Avan, a victim of domestic violence, was found dead in her home on August 4, with Turner charged with entering her home and killing her the previous day. Turner pleaded not guilty, and the case remains under investigation by the Los Angeles Police Department.

title: Dow rises 160 points to close at a record after Senate passes $1 trillion infrastructure bill
summary: Stocks, specifically the Dow and S&P 500, hit new records on Tuesday after the Senate passed a $1 trillion infrastructure package, boosting economically sensitive stocks. While the Dow and S&P 500 saw gains, the Nasdaq Composite dipped due to rising Treasury yields impacting tech stocks. Investors are now looking ahead to upcoming inflation data and statements from central bank speakers for further market direction.

title: The RealReal is Close to Settling Shareholder Stock-Drop Suit Over the Company's Authentication Claims
summary: The RealReal is nearing a settlement in a 2019 shareholder lawsuit accusing the company and its executives of misleading investors about its authentication process, artificially inflating stock prices. The agreement comes after continued discussions, with plaintiffs seeking preliminary approval for the settlement within 60 days. This settlement could impact other related lawsuits, including one from another shareholder and an ongoing legal battle with Chanel, while The RealReal recently reported increased Gross Merchandise Volume and Average Order Value for July.

title: Bank of America Corp. stock outperforms market on strong trading day
summary: Bank of America Corp. (BAC) stock rose 1.96% on Thursday, outperforming the broader market indexes like the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average. The stock closed below its 52-week high but showed mixed performance compared to competitors like JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo, which also saw gains. Trading volume for Bank of America was below its 50-day average.

title: Mubadala Capital's Blue Whale Acquisition Corp I Announces Pricing of $200 Million Initial Public Offering
summary: Blue Whale Acquisition Corp I, sponsored by Mubadala Capital, announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 20,000,000 units at $10.00 per unit, totaling $200 million. The units will trade on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "BWCAU" starting August 4, 2021. The company aims to pursue business combinations in the media, entertainment, and technology industries.

title: Stock Yards to Acquire Commonwealth Bank & Trust
summary: Stock Yards Bank & Trust has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Commonwealth Bank & Trust in a combined stock and cash transaction valued at approximately $153 million. Both financial institutions are based in Louisville with locations in Northern Kentucky, and the acquisition aims to expand services and locations for customers. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2021, subject to regulatory approval, and will result in combined assets of approximately $7.4 billion.

title: HollyFrontier and Holly Energy Partners Add Sinclair Dinosaur for $1.8B
summary: Dallas-based HollyFrontier Corporation and Holly Energy Partners announced an agreement to acquire and combine with Sinclair Oil from the Sinclair Corporation in a deal valued at $1.8 billion. The newly formed company will be called HF Sinclair Corporation, headquartered in Dallas, and will replace HollyFrontier in public trading on the NYSE. The acquisition includes Sinclair's market branding, commercial activities, renewable diesel business, and two Rocky Mountain area refineries, consistent with the company's growth strategy.

title: Open-banking: Real-time analytics for small and medium-sized enterprises
summary: This article discusses how Open Banking initiatives can provide real-time analytics for Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs), addressing their challenges in accessing external financing due to information asymmetry. Moody's, in collaboration with Credit Data Research and CRIF, has developed a solution to process Open Banking data, construct real-time financial statements, and generate up-to-date financial metrics for improved credit assessment and financial planning. The solution aims to enhance the efficiency of credit origination and monitoring for lenders and empower business owners with better insights into their finances.

title: A breakdown of US value ETFs
summary: This article analyzes five US value ETFs, highlighting that only three of them outperformed Vanguard's S&P 500 ETF despite 2021 being anticipated as a strong year for value factor resurgence. It details the methodologies, holdings, and performance of each ETF (iShares Edge MSCI USA Value Factor UCITS ETF, Ossiam Shiller Barclays Cape US Sector Value UCITS ETF, UBS ETF Factor MSCI USA Value UCITS ETF, UBS ETF Factor MSCI USA Prime Value UCITS ETF, and SPDR MSCI USA Value Weighted UCITS ETF) and discusses the importance of index design and Total Expense Ratios (TERs) in their relative performance.

title: Former Bank of America uptown tower changes hands in $271.5M deal
summary: Cousins Properties Inc. has sold its uptown tower, One South at the Plaza (formerly Bank of America Plaza), for $271.5 million to Tourmaline Capital Partners. The sale follows Bank of America's departure as the anchor tenant at the end of 2020, prompting the rebranding of the building earlier in the year.

title: RxSight, Inc. Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering
summary: RxSight, Inc. announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 7,350,000 shares of common stock at $16.00 per share, expecting to raise $117.6 million. The company's common stock is anticipated to begin trading on the Nasdaq Global Market under the ticker symbol "RXST" on July 30, 2021. J.P. Morgan Securities LLC and BofA Securities, Inc. are serving as joint book-running managers for the offering.

title: Sérgio Rial to take over as chairman of Santander Brazil’s board of directors as of January 2022
summary: Sérgio Rial, CEO of Santander Brazil and regional head of South America for the Santander Group, will become chairman of Santander Brazil’s board of directors starting January 1, 2022. Mario Roberto Opice Leão will succeed Rial as CEO of Santander Brazil, and Carlos Rey de Vicente will become the regional head of South America for Santander Group. These leadership changes aim to continue the bank's successful growth strategy and foster a strong, diverse management team.

title: Carrier Announces Agreement to Sell its Chubb Fire & Security Business to APi Group Corporation
summary: Carrier Global Corporation announced its agreement to sell its Chubb fire and security business to APi Group Corporation for an enterprise value of $3.1 billion. This sale allows Carrier to concentrate on its core businesses and reallocate proceeds to strategic priorities such as organic and inorganic growth, dividends, and share repurchases. The transaction is expected to close in late Q4 2021 or early Q1 2022, subject to consultation processes and regulatory approvals.

title: Clarios IPO
summary: Clarios, a global leader in automotive battery production and a subsidiary of Brookfield Asset Management, is listing on the NYSE under the ticker BTRY with a predicted market value of $11 billion. The company aims to raise $1.7 billion from its IPO, offering 88.1 million shares at $17 to $21, to pay down its debts. Clarios, which produces roughly one-third of the automotive industry’s battery technologies, makes money through sales of SLI, EFB, AGM, and lithium-ion batteries, primarily via its aftermarket channel, and plans to invest in advanced battery technology and expand its market share in China.

title: Candel Therapeutics Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering
summary: Candel Therapeutics announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 9,000,000 shares of common stock at $8.00 per share, expecting to raise $72 million. The shares are set to begin trading on Nasdaq under "CADL" on July 27, 2021, with the offering closing on July 29, 2021. The company has also granted underwriters a 30-day option to purchase an additional 1,350,000 shares.

title: The newest addition to the Charlotte skyline just opened near Bank of America Stadium
summary: The 29-story FNB Tower, a mixed-use development, officially opened in uptown Charlotte near Bank of America Stadium. It will serve as the regional headquarters for First National Bank, offering luxury apartments, office space, retail, and a sky-deck terrace. The environmentally-friendly building, which began construction in January 2019, is designed to achieve LEED Certification and Three Green Globes for sustainability.

title: Dow drops nearly 300 points on Friday, snaps 3-week winning streak
summary: U.S. stocks, including the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite, fell on Friday, snapping three-week winning streaks, as inflation fears overshadowed strong retail sales and earnings. The Dow lost 299.17 points, or 0.86%, closing at 34,687.85 and ending the week down 0.52%. Consumer sentiment declined in early July, with inflation expectations rising to levels not seen since August 2008, contributing to the market sell-off.

title: Stifel Announces Pricing of $300 Million of Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock
summary: Stifel Financial Corp. announced the pricing of a $300 million public offering of 12,000,000 depositary shares, each representing a 1/1000th interest in a share of 4.50% Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series D. Dividends will be payable quarterly at an annual rate of 4.50%, and the offering is expected to close on July 22, 2021. Stifel plans to use the proceeds to redeem its outstanding Series A Preferred Stock and for general corporate purposes.

title: Core & Main Has Filed to Go Public, IPO Date and Price Explained
summary: Core & Main, a company specializing in fire protection and water infrastructure products, has filed initial documents with the SEC to go public under the symbol CNM. The IPO is expected to offer nearly 34.9 million shares at a price range of $20–$23 apiece, aiming for a valuation of up to $7.5 billion and potentially raising $802.3 million. Investment funds of private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice (CD&R) currently own Core & Main and will control about 79.6 percent of the company after the IPO is completed.

title: Bank of America reports a big profit, and Citi and Wells Fargo beat expectations. (Published 2021)
summary: Bank of America reported a significant profit increase in the second quarter of 2021, more than doubling its earnings from the previous year, partly due to releasing funds set aside for loan losses. Citigroup and Wells Fargo also surpassed analysts' expectations, benefiting from consumers' increased spending and a recovering economy. Despite these strong earnings, Bank of America's revenue dropped, and its stock price fell as investors questioned the sustainability of loan growth amidst a potentially slowing economic rebound.

title: Japan's SMFG to buy nearly 5% of Jefferies for $386 million
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group Inc (SMFG) plans to acquire nearly 5% of Jefferies Financial Group Inc shares for $386 million to bolster its U.S. presence. The two companies will also form a partnership for cross-border M&A opportunities involving Japanese firms, and SMFG will provide substantial credit facilities to support Jefferies' lending. This move is part of SMFG's broader international expansion strategy, driven by limited growth opportunities in Japan.

title: Around the house: newly-public Utz Brands names first general counsel
summary: Newly-public US snacks maker Utz Brands has appointed Theresa Robbins Shea as its first general counsel as part of a broader leadership team expansion since going public last August. The article also highlights other significant in-house legal appointments, including Matthew Martin as chief counsel for First Citizens Bank, Michael Garson as general counsel for SOS International, Hannah Kim as chief legal officer for Neiman Marcus Group, Alan Halfenger as general counsel for Arctaris Impact Investors, and Andrea Soria as director of legal for Tonal Systems. These appointments reflect a trend of companies bolstering their legal and compliance departments with experienced professionals.

title: Shinhan promises a human touch at new Digilog branches
summary: Shinhan Bank has launched a new "Digilog" branch concept, aiming to combine digital technology with a human touch in a cafe-like setting. These branches offer digital services, financial seminars, and traditional banking counters, intending to differentiate Shinhan from big tech companies entering finance. The first three Digilog branches have opened in Seoul and Incheon, with another planned for Hanyang University.

title: Authentic Brands Group Files For IPO
summary: Authentic Brands Group (ABG), owner of numerous fashion and sports brands, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO). The company plans to sell $100 million worth of stock, though this is a placeholder amount. ABG generates over $14 billion in annual retail sales and reported net income of $225 million in 2020.

title: SentinelOne Announces Underwriters’ Full Exercise of Greenshoe Option and Closing of Initial Public Offering
summary: SentinelOne announced the closing of its initial public offering, including the full exercise of the underwriters' overallotment option. The company sold 40,250,000 shares of Class A common stock at $35.00 per share, generating approximately $1.33 billion in net proceeds. Concurrently, SentinelOne sold an additional 1,428,568 shares to existing stockholders in a private placement at the same public offering price.

title: Caroline Silver Joins Adobe International Advisory Board
summary: Caroline Silver, an Advisory Partner at Moelis & Company and a veteran in international investment banking, has been appointed to the Adobe International Advisory Board. This board, chaired by Paul Robson, President International at Adobe, aims to support Adobe's customers in developing and implementing digital transformation strategies. Silver's extensive experience will be valuable in helping clients, including major financial institutions, adapt and thrive in the digital economy.

title: Wells Fargo: Out of the Penalty Box and Back Into the Business of Credit Cards
summary: Wells Fargo is re-entering the consumer credit card market after its past scandal, with new offerings like the Wells Fargo Active Cash Card. Under CEO Charles Scharf, who has a strong background in payments, the company aims to leverage its extensive branch network to become a top credit card issuer. This move is expected to intensify competition and lead to new credit card products across the industry.

title: Bank of America ranks No. 1 in financial advice, per J.D. Power study
summary: Bank of America has been recognized by J.D. Power as the top financial institution for financial advice among its peers. This ranking highlights the bank's performance in a recent study, affirming its position in consumer satisfaction for financial advisory services.

title: Intapp Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering
summary: Intapp, Inc. announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 10,500,000 shares of common stock at $26.00 per share. The shares are expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol “INTA” on June 30, 2021. The offering is handled by J.P. Morgan, BofA Securities, and Credit Suisse Securities (USA) LLC as lead book-running managers.

title: JPMorgan makes Brazilian retail banking debut with 40% stake in C6 Bank
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has acquired a 40% stake in Brazilian digital bank C6 Bank, marking its entry into retail banking in Latin America's largest economy. This move follows other global banks' departures from Brazilian retail but capitalizes on the growth of digital banking and recent regulatory reforms. C6 Bank plans to use the investment to launch new credit lines and projects reaching 10 million clients by year-end, despite anticipated losses this year due to its growth focus.

title: Sabemos lo que hiciste con nuestro ahorro pensional - El pecado original de las AFP
summary: Cuestión Pública uncovered that Colombian pension savings, managed by AFPs controlled by Grupo AVAL and GEA, were invested in controversial projects like the Ruta del Sol (Odebrecht) and financial schemes similar to Interbolsa. These "self-investments" within their own economic groups, initially prohibited but later deregulated by the Santos and Duque administrations, raise conflict of interest concerns, prompting questions about regulatory oversight and the impact on pensioners' funds. The article details how regulatory changes facilitated these investments and explores the financial implications and alleged abuses of power.

title: LAURA ALBER NAMED TO BARRON’S TOP CEO LIST 2021
summary: Williams-Sonoma, Inc. President and CEO Laura Alber has been named to Barron’s Top CEO List 2021, recognized for guiding the company through the COVID-19 pandemic with robust e-commerce and relevant products. The list highlights leaders who successfully positioned their companies for future growth, with Barron's also acknowledging Williams-Sonoma's commitment to gender equity and environmental sustainability, including a goal of carbon neutrality by 2025.

title: Wells Fargo’s Next Play: The Self-Directed Channel
summary: Wells Fargo is considering a significant push into the self-directed investment channel, potentially through acquiring a brokerage platform or rebranding its WellsTrade platform. This move aims to capture more assets and next-generation investors, following similar strategies by competitors like Morgan Stanley and Bank of America. The expansion's feasibility may depend on the Federal Reserve lifting a regulatory asset cap on Wells Fargo.

title: TD Bank to Launch Low-Cost Deposit Account, Expanding Account Offerings in Support of Unbanked Households
summary: TD Bank announced the upcoming launch of TD Essential Banking, a low-cost, no-overdraft-fee deposit account designed to serve unbanked and underbanked households. This initiative is part of broader efforts to expand product offerings, including changes to overdraft policies and consumer lending, and to enhance financial education tools. The goal is to provide more accessible and affordable financial services to underserved communities.

title: Morgan Stanley says no vaccine, no entry. (Published 2021)
summary: Morgan Stanley announced that starting July 12, employees, clients, and visitors must attest to being fully vaccinated against the coronavirus to enter its New York City and Westchester County buildings. Unvaccinated staff will be required to work remotely. This policy aims to allow the bank to relax other pandemic protocols like mask-wearing and social distancing, aligning with moves by other major financial institutions.

title: Blackstone Bets $6 Billion on Buying and Renting Homes - WSJ
summary: Blackstone Group Inc. is acquiring Home Partners of America Inc., a company that buys and rents single-family homes, in a $6 billion deal. This acquisition signals Wall Street's belief that the U.S. housing market will remain robust. Home Partners of America owns over 17,000 houses and offers tenants the option to eventually purchase the homes they rent.

title: William Kaufman, Travelers Cos. Seal $185M Loan for 437 Madison Avenue
summary: The William Kaufman Organization and The Travelers Companies have closed a $185 million refinance loan for 437 Madison Avenue, with Wells Fargo providing the new debt. This loan retires $145 million in existing debt from Bank of America and Apple Bank. Eastdil Secured brokered the deal on behalf of the owners.

title: Bank of America makes Juneteenth a holiday, joining JPMorgan, Wells Fargo
summary: Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, and Wells Fargo will recognize Juneteenth as a paid holiday, joining other financial institutions in response to President Biden signing it into law. While these banks will offer floating holidays this year and add it to regular schedules next year, financial markets like the NYSE and Nasdaq are still determining whether to close. This move reflects a broader industry response to racial inequality following the murder of George Floyd.

title: Juneteenth, Now a Federal Holiday, Puts Companies to Work on a Response
summary: Following President Biden's signing of a bill making Juneteenth a federal holiday, companies across the U.S. are scrambling to determine how to acknowledge it. This includes deciding whether to offer paid time off, with some, like Goldman Sachs and Bank of America, quickly implementing new policies. The new holiday has prompted a rapid response from employers.

title: Goldman Sachs welcomes bankers back to the office with live music, food trucks
summary: Goldman Sachs welcomed bankers back to its New York offices with live music, food trucks, and free fitness classes to ease their return after CEO David Solomon's strong push against remote work. Other Wall Street firms like Barclays, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley are also planning their returns, with varying approaches to office mandates and COVID-19 restrictions. Morgan Stanley's James Gorman notably warned employees to return by Labor Day or face pay cuts, emphasizing the importance of in-office presence.

title: Bank of America Makes Juneteenth a Holiday, Joining JPMorgan, Wells Fargo
summary: Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase are making Juneteenth a company holiday starting next year, following President Joe Biden's signing of the federal holiday into law. Employees will receive a floating paid day off this year as June 19 falls on a Saturday. Wells Fargo is also observing Juneteenth as a federal holiday starting in 2022.

title: Morgan Stanley, Bank of America CEOs break relative silence on office returns
summary: CEOs of Morgan Stanley and Bank of America have signaled a strong desire for employees to return to the office, setting Labor Day as a benchmark for this transition. James Gorman of Morgan Stanley and Brian Moynihan of Bank of America emphasized the importance of in-person work for culture, learning, and client interaction, while also addressing vaccination status and compensation expectations. Their push aligns with other major bank CEOs who have expressed increasing impatience with remote work arrangements.

title: South Africa
summary: Barclays Private Bank has established an office in Johannesburg, South Africa, to provide offshore private, investment, and corporate banking expertise to South African clients. They leverage their global strength to help ultra-high net-worth individuals, their families, and family offices achieve financial ambitions, offering personalized service, wealth management strategies, and a wide choice of banking, investment, and advisory services. Potential clients are required to establish an investment portfolio of at least £5 million (or local currency equivalent).

title: California bank is shutting 2 of its 5 branches in SLO County
summary: Bank of the Sierra is closing two of its five branches in San Luis Obispo County (Arroyo Grande and Atascadero) on June 18, which is part of a larger plan by Sierra Bancorp to close five branches outside its primary market area. This decision is attributed to changes in customer behavior due to the COVID-19 pandemic and an efficiency review. The closures reflect a national trend of banks shutting down brick-and-mortar locations, with a record net loss of 2,284 branches in 2020.

title: Remote work unwind: Goldman spearheads Wall St return to office
summary: Goldman Sachs is leading a push for Wall Street employees to return to the office, requiring nearly all New York staff back from Monday, June 14, 2021. This contrasts with other firms like Citigroup, which are offering more flexibility and hybrid models. The varying approaches are causing both optimism for the city's economy and anxiety among employees regarding fairness, flexibility, and career impact.

title: Mike Branca Joins Regions Bank to Lead Total Rewards
summary: Regions Bank announced that Michael “Mike” Branca has been named head of Total Rewards, where he will oversee the development and administration of compensation and benefits plans. Branca brings 31 years of financial services experience, including leadership roles at Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and MBNA. He replaces Jill Shelton, who will retire at the end of the year after 16 years with Regions and a 40-year career in human resources.

title: BofA’s Pay to Card Brings the Bank Into the Fast-Developing Market for Speedy Payouts
summary: Bank of America has launched Pay to Card, a new service allowing fast payouts to consumers globally, responding to increased demand from the gig economy and e-commerce growth. The service processes payments within five minutes domestically and often within half an hour internationally, leveraging debit card details for consistency across borders. Analysts see BofA having an advantage due to its existing business clients and consumers compared to fintechs that have developed similar payout platforms.

title: Moody's keeps stable view on banks in China
summary: Moody's Investors Service maintains a stable outlook on China's banking sector, citing the solid asset quality of Chinese lenders and the economy's sustained recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The firm upgraded the ratings outlook for several regional commercial lenders from negative to stable, but also highlighted potential long-term risks associated with the uncertain technological implementation of the green transformation. The banking sector has been proactively addressing credit risk, with significant disposal of nonperforming loans.

title: 1stdibs.com, Inc. Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering
summary: 1stdibs.com, Inc. announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 5,750,000 shares of common stock at $20.00 per share, expecting to raise $115 million. The shares are anticipated to begin trading on The Nasdaq Global Market under the ticker symbol “DIBS” on June 10, 2021, with the offering closing on June 14, 2021. The underwriters also have a 30-day option to purchase additional shares.

title: Regions Bank places $1B bet on home renovation market
summary: Regions Bank is acquiring EnerBank USA for $960 million in cash, aiming to significantly expand its presence in the home improvement lending market. EnerBank, a specialized lender with $2.8 billion in loan balances, works with a network of 10,000 contractors. This acquisition is part of Regions' strategy to deepen client relationships and reach new customers in the growing home renovation sector, which is projected to increase to $433 billion in 2021.

title: Top Banker Quits Italy State Bank as Mario Draghi Revamps Leadership
summary: Bank of America Corp. is hiring top investment banker Vito Lo Piccolo from Italy’s state-backed lender Cassa Depositi e Prestiti SpA. Lo Piccolo will join BofA's investment banking division as a managing director, covering M&A and capital markets, starting in July. This move coincides with an overhaul of Cassa Depositi e Prestiti's leadership under Prime Minister Mario Draghi.

title: MOVES Morgan Stanley hires ex BofA banker Rizzo to drive European client push - sources
summary: Morgan Stanley has hired former Bank of America banker Luigi Rizzo as vice chairman of investment banking for EMEA to bolster its client-facing efforts across Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. Rizzo, who previously led Bank of America's European corporate and investment banking, will advise clients on strategic combinations, especially as M&A markets rebound post-COVID. His appointment comes as Morgan Stanley seeks to capitalize on a strong M&A market, with global dealmaking volumes hitting record highs.

title: Lisa Pollina to step down as Non-Exec Director of IG Group
summary: Lisa Pollina has informed the Board of electronic trading major IG Group Holdings plc of her intention to step down as a Non-Executive Director on September 1, 2021. Pollina currently serves as an investment adviser to Ares Management and a Non-Executive Director of Munich RE, bringing extensive experience from her previous roles at RBC Capital Markets and Bank of America Securities. Her career also includes serving on various public and private corporate Boards and contributing to the Federal Reserve Bank's Working Group on Financial Markets.

title: BofA names Kevin Tracy new Rhode Island president
summary: Bank of America Corp. has appointed Kevin Tracy as the new Rhode Island market president, succeeding William F. Hatfield who is retiring in July. Tracy, who has been with the company for 35 years, will be responsible for managing and growing the bank's $8.6 billion in deposits and its 29 branches in the region. He is recognized for his contributions to small businesses, including facilitating $160 million in Paycheck Protection Program loans in 2020.

title: Nikki Graham retiring, David Bader to become new Austin market president for Bank of America
summary: Nikki Graham is retiring from Bank of America after 27 years, transitioning to a philanthropic role at The Hector and Gloria Lopez Foundation. David Bader will succeed her as the new Austin market president for Bank of America. This leadership change marks a significant development for Bank of America's presence in the Austin market.

title: Banking: The biggest N.C.-based banks and credit unions
summary: North Carolina-based banks and credit unions experienced a significant rebound despite initial fears of an economic slump due to the pandemic, with many reversing reserves and seeing deposits surge from federal stimulus. This article highlights several key institutions and their performance, including TRUIST FINANCIAL, FIRST CITIZENS BANCSHARES, LIVE OAK BANK, and TRULIANT FEDERAL CREDIT UNION, and notes the stability and growth within the state's financial sector. It also details notable events and financial achievements of various banks, as compiled for Business North Carolina's annual list.

title: What are the banks snapping up 90 of HSBC’s branches in America?
summary: HSBC is selling 90 of its US retail bank branches to Citizens Bank and Cathay Bank as part of its strategy to exit mass-market retail banking in the US and focus on wealthy clients and international corporations, particularly in Asia. Citizens Bank is a long-standing US financial institution, while Cathay Bank is a large bank founded by Chinese Americans, and this acquisition will expand their existing footprints. The move reflects HSBC's pivot to growing markets in Asia, shifting capital from underperforming businesses in the US and Europe.

title: What are Citizens Bank and Cathay Bank, the buyers of more than 90 of HSBC's US branches?
summary: HSBC is exiting its US retail banking business for mass-market customers and small businesses, selling 90 branches to Citizens Bank and Cathay Bank. Citizens Bank will acquire 80 branches on the East Coast, focusing on expanding its presence in major metropolitan areas, while Cathay Bank will take over 10 branches on the West Coast to broaden its California network. This strategic move allows HSBC to concentrate on wealthy clients and international corporations, shifting resources to higher-growth markets in Asia.

title: Graduating from Secured Credit Cards to General Purpose: KeyBank Hits a Chord
summary: This article highlights KeyBank's successful secured credit card program, which helps clients build or rebuild credit and graduate to general-purpose cards. It details how the program saved KeyCorp over $1.1 million in acquisition costs and significantly improved participants' FICO scores, positioning it as a good model for other issuers. The piece emphasizes the importance of secured cards as a responsible lending option, especially given the economic impacts of COVID-19.

title: Goldman Sachs Adds Kimberley Harris as Sixth Woman on Board of Directors
summary: Goldman Sachs announced the appointment of media lawyer Kimberley Harris to its board of directors, increasing the number of women on its board to six out of thirteen. This move aligns with the financial industry's growing push for diversity and Goldman's internal targets to elevate women into senior leadership roles. Harris brings extensive experience from NBCUniversal, Comcast Corporation, and government service to her new position.

title: Fincrime Briefing: Congress scrutinizes Deutsche Bank on AML, fines fuel EU de-risking, malware hijacks crypto blockchain, and more
summary: This Fincrime Briefing covers several key financial crime topics including a U.S. congressional probe into Deutsche Bank's AML controls, a wave of EU bank fines leading to de-risking, and a new malware strain hijacking Bitcoin's blockchain for resilience. The article details instances of alleged money laundering, the impact of regulatory crackdowns on banks' willingness to engage with high-risk regions, and the evolving tactics of cybercriminals using decentralized networks.
source: Association of Certified Financial Crime Specialists
source_domain: Association of Certified Financial Crime Specialists

title: Bank of America names leaders as it adjusts operations in consumer and small business unit
summary: Bank of America is reorganizing its consumer and small business unit to a new model it believes will offer more comprehensive client service. As part of these operational adjustments, the company has named new leaders for the unit. This move aims to enhance client experience and service delivery within these key segments.

title: Ana Botin and Andrea Orcel come face to face in Santander court battle
summary: A court battle has begun in Madrid between Santander chairman Ana Botín and former UBS banker Andrea Orcel over Santander's decision to not hire Orcel as CEO. Botín argued that Orcel never received a formal contract because terms were still being discussed, while Orcel is suing for tens of millions of euros in lost pay. The case was paused after UBS witnesses failed to appear.

title: JPMorgan Achieves Carbon Neutrality in Operations, Sets Carbon Reduction Financing Targets for High Emitting Sectors
summary: JPMorgan Chase announced it achieved carbon neutrality in its operations for 2020 and established new 2030 carbon intensity targets for high-emitting sectors like Oil & Gas, Electric Power, and Auto Manufacturing. These targets are part of its commitment to align financing activities with the Paris Agreement and facilitate $2.5 trillion in sustainable finance over the next decade. The company also outlined new sustainability goals for its own operations, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions and water consumption.

title: Bank of America, NACA commit to $15B in mortgages for low- to moderate-income buyers by 2027
summary: Bank of America and the Neighborhood Assistance Corp. of America (NACA) have announced a commitment to provide $15 billion in mortgages for low- to moderate-income homebuyers by May 2027. This expanded partnership aims to support affordable homeownership.

title: Bank of America to Raise U.S. Minimum Hourly Wage to $25 by 2025 - WSJ
summary: Bank of America announced plans to increase its hourly minimum wage to $25 by 2025, which would position it above its major banking counterparts and help address worker shortages. Furthermore, the bank will require all its U.S. vendors to pay employees dedicated to the bank at least $15 an hour. This move aligns with broader discussions around minimum wage increases and their economic impact.

title: BofA Joins Paxos Blockchain Stock-Settlement Network
summary: Bank of America Corp. has joined Paxos Trust Co.'s blockchain network to settle stock trades in minutes, marking a significant step in Wall Street's adoption of blockchain technology. This move makes BofA the largest addition to the Paxos Settlement Service, which previously included Credit Suisse Group AG and Nomura Holdings Inc.’s Instinet. The initiative aims to modernize equity trade settlement, potentially challenging traditional systems by enabling near real-time transactions.

title: XMLV: Shedding Volatility in the Market's 'Sweet Spot'
summary: The Invesco S&P MidCap Low Volatility ETF (XMLV) offers investors reduced volatility in the mid-cap segment, which has historically outperformed other market caps. Mid-caps are considered the market's "sweet spot" due to their strong economic contributions and responsiveness to GDP growth. XMLV's focus on low-volatility mid-cap stocks, particularly in cyclical sectors like financial services, industrials, and materials, positions it well for continued economic expansion.

title: Personalities of Pittsburgh: John H. Montgomery on becoming CEO at Community Bank during the pandemic
summary: John H. Montgomery became CEO of Community Bank (CB Financial Services Inc.) during the pandemic, a significant leadership change. The article discusses his Pittsburgh ties and his perspective on the evolving banking landscape. It also includes related articles concerning local bank activities in the Pittsburgh area.

title: Reputation rankings show Wells Fargo's massive rehabilitation campaign may have worked
summary: Wells Fargo's significant public rehabilitation campaign launched in 2018 appears to have successfully improved its reputation. After hitting historic lows in ethics scores following a series of scandals, the bank's reputation has recovered considerably, though it still lags behind some competitors. This improvement is part of a broader trend of banks generally seeing improved public perception, despite remaining largely "unloved."

title: Bank of America names Harlem native Tavarez president of New York City
summary: Bank of America has appointed Harlem native Jose Tavarez as president of Bank of America New York City and Westchester County. Tavarez has been with the bank for 25 years. This move highlights Bank of America's continued strategic appointments in key regional markets.

title: Bank of America reaches $75 mln settlement over excessive fees
summary: Bank of America has agreed to a $75 million settlement in a class-action lawsuit accusing it of charging excessive overdraft fees. The settlement addresses charges for repeatedly attempting to process single transactions, and as part of the agreement, the bank will cease imposing multiple fees on "retry" payments for at least five years, saving customers an estimated $318 million.

title: On Bitcoin’s Energy Consumption
summary: This article quantitatively analyzes Bitcoin's energy consumption, comparing it to the gold industry and the traditional banking system. It argues that while Bitcoin's energy use is substantial, it is verifiable and serves to secure the network, offering financial freedom and potential benefits to the energy sector. The piece concludes that given Bitcoin's utility and the inherent subjectivity of energy value judgments, its energy consumption is acceptable.

title: Centerview Hires Three BofA Bankers in Technology Push
summary: Centerview Partners has reportedly hired three senior Bank of America investment bankers, including co-head Jack MacDonald, to bolster its technology sector team. This move also includes experienced technology bankers Steve Miller and Gary Kirkham, indicating Centerview's strategic push into the technology investment banking space.

title: JPMorgan Is America’s Largest Company In 2021, But Amazon Is Rising In The Ranks
summary: Despite a pandemic, America's largest companies grew significantly in 2021, with JPMorgan Chase maintaining its position as the largest for the third consecutive year. Meanwhile, Amazon climbed into the top five, reflecting the growing importance of e-commerce, while traditional giants like AT&T and ExxonMobil saw significant drops in rankings. This year's Global 2000 ranking illustrates the resilience and shifts within the U.S. corporate landscape amidst economic volatility.

title: Local Bank of America exec Charles Bowman shifts roles as part of retirement plan
summary: Bank of America executive Charles Bowman has transitioned roles, stepping down as Charlotte market president but retaining his position as North Carolina president, as he prepares for retirement in 2022. Kieth Cockrell will take over as Charlotte market president. This move is part of his long-term retirement plan, following almost 15 years in the Charlotte market president role.

title: MP Materials (MP) Is an Attractive Play on Rare Earths
summary: MP Materials (MP) is presented as an attractive long-term investment due to its position as the largest rare-earth materials producer outside of China. The article discusses why the stock has fallen recently despite strong earnings and highlights the strategic importance of rare earths, especially given global reliance on China. It also includes analyst ratings and a price prediction, suggesting a significant upside.

title: BofA Promotes Brunner, Farman to Run M&A Amid Deal Windfall
summary: Bank of America Corp. has appointed Kevin Brunner and Ivan Farman as co-heads of its global mergers and acquisitions business. These promotions follow a record surge in investment-banking fees for the company. Brunner and Farman previously led the M&A business for BofA in the Americas.

title: World’s Best Banks 2021: North America
summary: North American banks demonstrated resilience and innovation in 2020 amid the challenges posed by the Covid-19 pandemic. Royal Bank of Canada was recognized as the overall Best Bank in North America for its customer service and technological advancements, while Bank of America maintained its position as Best Bank in the United States by enhancing digital capabilities and client experience. Butterfield Bank was named Best Bank in Bermuda, highlighting its conservative underwriting and diversified portfolio.

title: ACT IPO News - Mortgage insurance spinoff Enact Holdings sets terms for $497 million IPO
summary: Enact Holdings, a mortgage insurance company being spun out of Genworth Financial, announced terms for its $497 million IPO. The company plans to offer 22.6 million shares at a price range of $20 to $24, valuing the company at $3.6 billion at the midpoint. Enact, which is a leading private mortgage insurance provider in the US, generated $1.1 billion in sales for the 12 months ended December 31, 2020, and is expected to list on Nasdaq under the symbol ACT.

title: Bank of America's 'Erica' trademark win partly upheld by 10th Circuit
summary: The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals partly upheld Bank of America's trademark win for its ERICA mobile banking assistant, ruling it did not infringe on one of Erik Underwood's trademarks and upholding the cancellation of another. However, the court remanded a decision regarding Underwood's "E.R.I.C.A." mark, stating the lower court applied the wrong standard and Underwood may still have protectable rights. The ruling clarifies the criteria for trademark "use in commerce" under the Lanham Act.

title: BofA Hit Hardest as EU Fines Bond-Trading Trio $34 Million
summary: The European Union fined Bank of America, Credit Suisse, and Credit Agricole a total of 28.5 million euros ($34 million) for colluding in bond-trading chatrooms. Bank of America received the largest penalty, while Deutsche Bank avoided a fine by being the first to report the illegal activity. The collusion involved U.S. supra-sovereign, sovereign, and agency bonds.

title: Bank of Hawaii achieves record earnings, deposits and assets
summary: Bank of Hawaii Corp. reported record earnings, deposits, and assets in the first quarter of 2021, driven by a release of $14.3 million from its loan-loss reserve and an anticipated economic recovery in Hawaii. The bank's net income rose to $59.9 million, with earnings per share of $1.50, exceeding analyst estimates. Bankoh also saw record high deposits of $19.56 billion and assets of $21.95 billion, while continuing to invest in digital banking services.

title: As Ally makes big move in uptown Charlotte, online bank sees more growth ahead
summary: Ally Financial is solidifying its presence in Charlotte with the debut of the Ally Charlotte Center, consolidating multiple offices into one hub. The $182 billion financial-services company's move signifies its growth and establishment as a major player in the region, joining other large banks on Tryon Street. This expansion is part of Ally's continued strategy for growth, including in areas like auto lending and innovation labs.

title: National Grid Is Said to Pick Banks for $7 Billion Gas Asset Sale
summary: National Grid Plc has reportedly hired Barclays Plc, Goldman Sachs Group Inc., and Robey Warshaw LLP to advise on the sale of a majority stake in its gas grid business. This stake could be valued at up to 5 billion pounds ($6.9 billion). The move comes as the utility prepares for a low-carbon future, utilizing the same advisors who recently assisted in its largest-ever acquisition.

title: Recursion Pharmaceuticals Announces Closing of Initial Public Offering
summary: Recursion Pharmaceuticals announced the closing of its initial public offering on April 20, 2021, which included the full exercise of the underwriters' option to purchase additional shares. The company sold 27,878,787 shares of Class A common stock at $18.00 per share, generating gross proceeds of $501.8 million. The shares began trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol "RXRX" on April 16, 2021.

title: Bank of America looks to expand Leader on Loan program in new markets
summary: Bank of America is planning to expand its "Leader on Loan" program into new markets. This program allows bank executives to assist local organizations, leveraging their business expertise for community benefit. The expansion aims to accelerate work at various non-profit and community-focused groups.

title: Broadway Financial Completes Merger to Create Largest Black-Owned Bank in the US
summary: Broadway Financial Corp. completed its merger with Washington, D.C.-based CFC Banc Corp. on April 1, forming CityFirstBroadway, now the largest Black-led bank in the U.S. with over $1 billion in assets. The new institution plans to expand commercial lending, develop affordable housing, and offer loans to small businesses in underserved urban areas. This merger occurred despite a significant decline in the number of Black-owned financial institutions nationwide.

title: Bank of America CEO Moynihan says supports ‘a well-focused infrastructure plan’ - CNN interview
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan stated in a CNN interview that he supports a "well-focused infrastructure plan" for the U.S. He also commented on the potential impact of a 28 percent corporate tax rate, noting it would depend on the new tax law's details.

title: Northern Trust to launch FX trading engine in Singapore
summary: Northern Trust is set to launch an electronic FX pricing and trading engine in Singapore, becoming the latest major bank to join the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) initiative to develop the region into a global FX trading hub. This move expands Northern Trust's FX solutions in Asia-Pacific, following prior efforts to grow its FX trading business through acquisitions and partnerships with firms like BEx and Lumint. The new eFX platform aims to benefit regional market participants with improved speed, enhanced pricing discovery, and more efficient execution.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America announced a doubling of its profit in the first quarter of the year, reaching $8.05 billion, largely due to releasing reserves previously set aside for potential bad loans. This performance significantly surpassed its earnings of $4.01 billion from a year prior, when banks were heavily provisioning for the economic impact of the pandemic. While profits soared, the bank's revenue remained flat, beating analysts' expectations.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America announced its profit doubled in the first quarter of the year, reaching $8.05 billion, largely due to releasing reserves previously set aside for bad loans. This marks a significant increase from $4.01 billion a year prior when banks were building up reserves at the start of the pandemic. The first-quarter results surpassed analysts' expectations, despite revenue remaining flat.

title: KKR-backed AppLovin raises $2 billion in U.S. IPO at over $28 billion valuation
summary: Mobile app and gaming company AppLovin Corp successfully priced its initial public offering at $80 per share, raising $2 billion and valuing the company at $28.64 billion. Backed by KKR & Co Inc, AppLovin is listing on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the ticker symbol "APP." This IPO highlights the surging demand for video games during the COVID-19 pandemic, with AppLovin boasting over 410 million daily active users and more than 200 free-to-play mobile games.

title: Bank of America management offers optimistic outlook on economy, reserves
authors: Noor Zainab Hussain and Elizabeth Dilts Marshall
summary: Bank of America executives expressed an optimistic outlook for economic growth, citing strong consumer spending and financial markets after better-than-expected first-quarter profits. The bank released $2.7 billion in loan loss reserves and expects to release more as the economy improves, despite challenges from low interest rates and one-off expenses. Analysts remain positive on the bank’s future growth prospects, anticipating a rise in net interest income.

title: BofA Shares Slide as Tepid Loan Growth Counters Trading Bonanza
summary: Bank of America (BAC) saw its shares decline by as much as 4.2% despite strong performance from its trading and investment banking divisions. This drop was attributed to a decrease in loan balances and higher-than-expected pandemic-related costs, which outweighed the revenue surge from trading and banking fees. The bank also released $2.7 billion of reserves, signaling an improving economic outlook.

title: JPMorgan Chase’s mortgage margins narrow in Q1
summary: JPMorgan Chase saw its mortgage margins narrow in the first quarter of 2021 despite a 21% increase in originations over the previous quarter. Production revenue from mortgage fees declined, and gain-on-sale margins fell significantly due to market factors and a shift towards lower-margin correspondent lending. CEO Jamie Dimon anticipates a "Goldilocks moment" for the economy.

title: Gap to Replace Longtime Credit-Card Issuer Synchrony With Barclays
summary: Gap Inc. is ending its 22-year partnership with Synchrony Financial, its longtime credit-card issuer, and moving its business to Barclays PLC. Barclays will now manage Gap's private-label and co-branded credit cards, including those for Athleta, Banana Republic, and Old Navy. The portfolio includes approximately 11 million open card accounts with a total balance of roughly $3.8 billion as of the end of March.

title: Firstrust, M&T participate in grant programs to help local small businesses
summary: Firstrust and M&T Bank are participating in grant programs designed to assist local small businesses in their expansion efforts. This initiative comes as several local banks are finding ways to provide assistance to businesses beyond the Paycheck Protection Program. The article highlights these banks' commitment to supporting the local business community.

title: BMO sells EMEA asset management business for $1.1-billion to Ameriprise Financial
summary: Bank of Montreal is selling its European, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) asset management business to Ameriprise Financial Inc. for $1.1-billion. This divestiture is part of BMO's strategy to focus on North America and improve its efficiency ratio, despite the sale price being lower than its original acquisition cost. The deal is expected to boost BMO's capital levels and marks a new strategic relationship with Ameriprise's asset management arm, Columbia Threadneedle Investments.

title: JPMorgan Chase wants to be the commercial bank for ‘green economy’ companies
summary: JPMorgan Chase is establishing a new Green Economy team within its commercial banking division to deepen relationships with companies focused on environmentally-friendly products, services, and conservation. This initiative aims to provide capital and expertise to businesses across renewable energy, efficiency solutions, agriculture and food technology, and sustainable finance. The move aligns with the broader financial industry's shift towards a low-carbon economy, as highlighted by CEO Jamie Dimon.

title: Cadence Bank agrees to merge with Mississippi lender in $6B deal
summary: Cadence Bank has announced an all-stock merger with BancorpSouth Bank, creating an entity with a market value exceeding $6 billion and assets around $44 billion. The combined company, to be named Cadence Bank, will have dual headquarters in Tupelo, Miss., and Houston, with shareholders of Cadence Bank receiving 0.70 shares of BancorpSouth stock and a cash dividend of $1.25 per share. The transaction is expected to finalize in the fourth quarter, establishing the fifth-largest institution in Texas and the Southeast.

title: Citi, BofA Want to Save Traders’ Time With Fixed-Income Platform
summary: Citigroup Inc. and Bank of America Corp. are developing a new fixed-income trading platform aimed at making CLO traders more productive. The platform will initially focus on streamlining the manual process of compiling bid lists for "bid wanted in competition" (BWICs) auctions, a time-consuming task that currently generates little revenue for banks. The two banks plan to invite other dealers to participate in the new trading venue.

title: Duke Energy, Wells Fargo, NextEra Energy Resources join forces on major solar expansion in North Carolina
summary: Wells Fargo has joined Duke Energy's Green Source Advantage (GSA) program, partnering with NextEra Energy Resources to develop a 58-megawatt solar power plant in Catawba County, North Carolina. This project, known as Blackburn Solar, is expected to come online in 2022 and will offset about 50 percent of Wells Fargo’s energy usage in the state. The GSA program allows large customers to achieve sustainability goals by securing renewable energy from projects connected to the Duke Energy grid, contributing to North Carolina's solar expansion.

title: AmEx's purchase of online lender Kabbage left desperate PPP borrowers in the cold
summary: American Express's acquisition of Kabbage in August 2020 created significant problems for small businesses seeking second-round PPP loans. While AmEx bought Kabbage's lending technology, it left behind the PPP loan book, which became K Servicing. This orphaned entity is now plagued with customer complaints, delays, and a lack of support, leaving many desperate borrowers without critical funding and struggling to navigate the complex process.

title: Bank Of America Adds AxiaMed To Its Merchants Payments Regimen
summary: Bank of America has acquired Axia Technologies, also known as AxiaMed, to enhance its merchant payments regimen, specifically targeting the healthcare sector. AxiaMed provides an integrated payments platform for healthcare providers, addressing the industry's historical lag in payment advancements and expanding Bank of America's merchant services capabilities. This acquisition follows Bank of America's decision to build its own proprietary payments platform after dissolving its joint venture with Fiserv.

title: Fifth Third Bancorp stock rises Monday, still underperforms market
summary: Fifth Third Bancorp stock (FITB) rose 0.66% on Monday, closing at $38.23, although it still underperformed the broader market, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average seeing larger gains. The stock remained below its 52-week high and showed mixed performance compared to competitors like Bank of America and Wells Fargo. Trading volume was also below its 50-day average.

title: An Acquisition of AxiaMed Helps BofA’s Effort to Rebuild Its Acquiring Business
summary: Bank of America acquired Axia Technologies Inc. (AxiaMed) to bolster its merchant-acquiring business, specifically targeting the healthcare sector. AxiaMed offers integrated payment solutions for healthcare providers, supporting various payment methods and omnichannel integration. This acquisition is part of BofA's strategy to rebuild its acquiring services post-First Data partnership, aiming to compete effectively with financial-technology providers.

title: Turkey fines 10 foreign firms for illegal short selling
summary: Turkey's capital markets watchdog has imposed fines totaling $3.25 million on 10 foreign financial firms for unlawful short selling transactions. The fines were issued because the firms failed to notify brokerage houses that their transactions were short selling. Credit Suisse, Barclays, and Merrill Lynch BofA International received the largest penalties.

title: Black Media Execs Demand More Business From General Motors' Multi-Billion Dollar Ad Budget
summary: Black media executives are demanding that General Motors significantly increase its advertising spending with Black-owned media companies, pointing out that GM spent an allegedly abysmal 0.5% (or 2% according to GM) of its multi-billion dollar ad budget with them in 2019. The article highlights the financial capacity of GM and compares its investment in Black businesses to other major companies and individuals who have pledged substantial funds to racial justice and Black-owned enterprises. The author argues that a larger allocation of GM's ad budget to Black-owned media would create Black jobs and significantly change the landscape of these companies while still reaching Black audiences.

title: Who is Behind Archegos?
summary: The article identifies Bill Hwang, a "tiger cub" hedgie with a past insider trading conviction, as the figure behind Archegos Capital Management, whose colossal margin calls are impacting major banks. Archegos's forced liquidation of an estimated $30 billion in block trades, including shares in Chinese firms, affected banks like Credit Suisse and Nomura after prime brokers demanded more collateral.

title: Goldman takes heat for first-year analysts’ 100-hour workweeks
summary: Goldman Sachs is under scrutiny after a survey revealed its first-year analysts are working nearly 100-hour weeks, leading to deteriorating health and a souring outlook. CEO David Solomon responded by promising to strengthen the firm's "Saturday rule" and accelerate hiring for junior bankers. Meanwhile, Jefferies offered its junior employees perks like Peloton bikes, which some see as a subtle recruitment jab in light of Goldman's controversy.

title: 2020 Annual Report
summary: The 2020 Goldman Sachs Annual Report highlights the firm's strong financial performance amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, with record revenues and significant progress on strategic goals. Chairman and CEO David M. Solomon details how the firm prioritized its people, clients, and communities, while also advancing sustainable finance and diversity and inclusion initiatives. The report emphasizes the firm's resilience and adaptability while navigating an extraordinary year.

title: Morgan Stanley becomes the first big U.S. bank to offer its wealthy clients access to bitcoin funds
summary: Morgan Stanley is the first major U.S. bank to offer its wealthy clients access to bitcoin funds, responding to client demand despite the cryptocurrency's volatility. The bank will provide access to three bitcoin funds with significant investment minimums and strict eligibility criteria, allowing investments up to 2.5% of a client's net worth. This move signifies a notable step for bitcoin's acceptance as an asset class within traditional finance.

title: Seeking return to normal, JPMorgan Chase is planning for summer interns to go to the office. (Published 2021)
summary: JPMorgan Chase is planning for summer interns in New York and London to work from the office, signaling a move towards pre-pandemic working life for big financial firms. The bank also intends to allow some employees to return to its London offices starting March 29, though at no more than 50% capacity. This decision reflects the eagerness of banks to re-establish in-office working, despite challenges, with leaders like Jamie Dimon and David Solomon expressing concerns about prolonged remote work.

title: Value is finally outpacing growth this year but will still falter long term, traders say
summary: Value stocks are currently outperforming growth stocks, with some traders like Steve Chiavarone of Federated Hermes expecting this trend to continue in 2021 due to economic reopening. However, Danielle Shay of Simpler Trading believes growth will ultimately win out long term, though she acknowledges value's current appeal for long-term investors. Both traders highlight the ongoing debate between investing in growth versus value and the difficulty of trading options in value stocks due to lower premium and momentum.

title: Timeline of Bryn Mawr Trust's 132-year path to a $976 million acquisition
summary: This article provides a timeline of Bryn Mawr Trust's 132-year history, culminating in its $976 million acquisition. It highlights the bank's long-standing roots in the Philadelphia Main Line area and references related articles concerning its acquisition and other business activities.

title: Goldman Sachs Unveils $10 Billion Push to Invest in Black Women
summary: Goldman Sachs announced a $10 billion commitment over the next decade to invest in businesses and organizations that benefit Black women, aiming to narrow the wealth gap. This initiative will focus on housing, healthcare, and other programs, alongside a $100 million philanthropic contribution. This move is part of a broader trend among major financial institutions addressing their historical role in racial wealth disparities.

title: Hilton Grand Vacations to acquire Diamond Resorts in $1.4B transaction
summary: Hilton Grand Vacations Inc. (HGV) has entered a definitive agreement to acquire Diamond Resorts International Inc. for approximately $1.4 billion in a stock-based transaction. This acquisition will combine HGV's brand strength with Diamond's independent timeshare operations, creating a premier vacation ownership company with expanded offerings and an anticipated $125 million in run-rate cost synergies. The transaction is expected to close in the summer, pending regulatory and shareholder approvals.

title: Gold Is at a Critical Juncture Now
summary: Technical analyst Clive Maund examines gold's recent price decline and its potential future movements, suggesting a likely imminent rally based on technical indicators and market behavior. The article analyzes various charts, including Larry's gold chart and broader market indices like the Wilshire 5000, to predict whether gold will break out or form a "Cup & Handle" pattern, and discusses the Fed's role in market stability.

title: Equitable Financial Inks 130 KSF Manhattan Lease
summary: Equitable Financial Life Insurance Co. has signed a 15-year lease for 130,000 square feet at 1345 Avenue of the Americas in Midtown Manhattan, moving its headquarters. This move reflects a broader trend among financial services firms to embrace office space, despite the increase in remote work options. The new location, owned by Fisher Brothers, is undergoing a $100 million-plus renovation to include high-end amenities.

title: Big 5 Sporting Goods Enters Into New Five-Year Credit Facility
summary: Big 5 Sporting Goods Corporation announced a new five-year loan agreement with Bank of America, N. A., maturing in February 2026. This agreement provides a secured revolving credit facility of up to $150 million, with an option to increase to $200 million. CFO Barry Emerson highlighted the favorable terms and the company's strong financial condition, anticipating that the facility will provide crucial financial flexibility.

title: JPMorgan exits Mexico private banking, refers clients to BBVA
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is exiting its private banking business in Mexico, referring its local clients to BBVA Mexico. This move follows a similar decision in Brazil and reflects a trend of wealthy Latin American clients shifting their assets to international financial centers. JPMorgan will continue to operate its other businesses in Mexico, including investment banking, trading, and treasury services, and will still serve Mexican clients through its offshore platform.

title: Bank of America retail president on building industry diversity, key growth strategies
summary: Steve Boland, president of retail at Bank of America, discussed the importance of diversity, the bank's future retail strategy, and consumer spending outlook for 2021. He highlighted the ongoing work needed to promote diversity within the industry. The article also touches upon BofA's investment in digital banking and its commitment to community development and affordable homeownership.

title: Reconnecting to CT: M&T Bank gets fresh start in state with People’s United acquisition
summary: M&T Bank, which previously struggled in Connecticut after acquiring Hudson City Savings Bank in 2015, is poised for a fresh start with its proposed $7.6 billion acquisition of People’s United Financial. The acquisition will significantly expand M&T's presence in Connecticut, where People's United has the largest branch network after Bank of America. M&T aims to preserve community relationships and customer-facing employees from People's United to ensure success in the new combined entity.

title: M&T Bank acquiring Bridgeport-based People’s United in $7.6B deal
summary: M&T Bank is acquiring Bridgeport-based People's United Bank in a $7.6 billion deal. M&T aims for $330 million in cost savings and synergies and plans to maintain People's United's Bridgeport office as its New England regional headquarters. The acquisition would end People's United's 179-year run as an independent Connecticut-based bank.

title: M&T Bank Agrees To Acquire People’s United Financial In Latest Tie-Up Of Regional Lenders
summary: M&T Bank announced its agreement to acquire People's United Financial in a $7.6 billion deal, continuing a trend of regional bank mergers driven by low interest rates and the need for technological investments. This acquisition will create a bank with $200 billion in assets and over 1,100 branches across 12 states, with M&T expecting the transaction to significantly boost its earnings per share by 2023. The merger reflects a broader strategy among regional lenders to scale up and compete more effectively with larger U.S. banks while adapting to evolving customer demands for digital banking.

title: BofA Names New Leaders in Fixed Income, FX After Departures
summary: Bank of America Corp. has appointed Michael Maras as the new head of global fixed-income, currencies, and commodities research, following David Woo's departure. Maras will continue to oversee research in the EMEA region from London and the bank also named a new head of currency trading for Brazil. These changes were communicated to staff via an internal memo.

title: Wells Fargo Advisors Embraces More Execs from Private Bank
summary: Wells Fargo Advisors has appointed Kent Caldwell-Meeks, Connie Degler, and Adam Taback to its management operating committee, signaling increased integration of private bank services into its financial advisory operations. This move is part of the company's broader strategy to enhance cross-selling opportunities for wealthy clients and better manage risk and costs under new leadership. The appointments reflect a significant push to combine private banking and advisory services, a shift that reverses previous leadership migrations within the company.

title: Asian Stocks Have Momentum in The Year of the Ox
summary: The article highlights China's economic resilience during the pandemic, with a surging export business and significant foreign direct investment, positioning it to potentially overtake the U.S. economy earlier than expected. Asian stock markets, particularly South Korea, Taiwan, and China, demonstrated strong performance in 2020 and continue to show momentum in the new year, driven by increased investor interest and massive infrastructure projects requiring substantial metal demand. The author predicts a strong outlook for Asian markets in the "Year of the Metal Ox," especially in sectors related to advanced technology and electric vehicles.

title: Silver as a Store of Value? Why Analysts Are Growing Bullish on the Metal
summary: Analysts are growing bullish on silver as a store of value, similar to gold, leading to increased interest in silver exchange-traded funds and trusts like the Sprott Physical Silver Trust (PSLV). Despite recent volatility influenced by retail traders, Bank of America maintains a bullish outlook, supported by easy monetary policies, a weak U.S. dollar, and emerging demand from renewable energy sectors. Moody's highlights silver's price sensitivity and its historical role as a medium of exchange, while also noting its smaller, less liquid market compared to other commodities.

title: Buffett's Berkshire reveals big stakes in Verizon, Chevron
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc revealed significant new investments, including an $8.6 billion stake in Verizon Communications Inc and a $4.1 billion stake in Chevron Corp, according to a regulatory filing. The conglomerate also disclosed a new $499 million stake in Marsh & McLennan Cos while reducing investments in companies like Apple and several banks. These moves signal where Buffett and his portfolio managers see value, deploying some of Berkshire's substantial cash hoard.

title: BofA, Citi Trim CEO Compensation for 2020 in Year of Restraint
summary: Bank of America and Citigroup both reduced their CEO's compensation for 2020, reflecting a year of economic restraint due to the pandemic. Brian Moynihan's pay at BofA was cut by 7.5% to $24.5 million, while outgoing Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat saw a 21% reduction to $19 million. This move highlights ongoing efforts by banks to manage executive payouts conservatively during a challenging economic period.

title: Cross-Currency Credit Spreads: Mind the Gap
summary: This article examines the divergence in corporate-bond spreads between USD and EUR markets, particularly during and after the COVID-19 crisis. It highlights that while Federal Reserve interventions addressed acute liquidity shortages, smaller discrepancies persisted, presenting both risks and opportunities for investors. The research suggests that the spread differential was largely driven by U.S. companies and potentially reflects a greater "home bias" among U.S. investors.

title: Klein's seventh SPAC Churchill Capital Corp VII more than triples deal size ahead of $1 billion IPO
summary: Churchill Capital Corp VII, a blank check company founded by dealmaker Michael Klein, has increased its proposed IPO deal size to $1.0 billion, up 233% from initial plans. The company aims to offer 100 million units at $10 each, with each unit comprising one share and one-fifth of a warrant. This SPAC, like Klein's others, intends to target businesses with stable free cash flow and strong management, and will list on the NYSE under the symbol CVII.U.

title: Vor Biopharma Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering
summary: Vor Biopharma announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 9,828,017 shares of common stock at $18.00 per share, expecting to raise approximately $176.9 million in gross proceeds. The shares are anticipated to begin trading on the Nasdaq Global Market under the ticker symbol "VOR" on February 5, 2021, with the offering expected to close on February 9, 2021. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, Evercore ISI, Barclays, and Stifel are acting as joint book-running managers.

title: As Silver Mania Fades, Focus on the Fundamentals, 'SLV'
summary: As the initial excitement around Reddit users driving up silver prices dwindles, investors are encouraged to refocus on the fundamentals of silver. The iShares Silver Trust (SLV) is highlighted as a suitable ETF for exposure to silver bullion, offering portfolio diversification and inflation protection. Bank of America remains bullish on silver, forecasting prices could reach $35, with a potential spike to $50, despite recent volatility.

title: Bank stocks jump as yields rise, but one trader says questions remain about the group longer term
summary: Bank stocks have seen a significant short-term boost due to rising bond yields and the prospect of further fiscal stimulus, with the Financial Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLF) and SPDR S&P Bank ETF (KBE) showing strong gains. However, Mark Newton of Newton Advisors suggests that for a sustained longer-term rally, the sector needs to break through key resistance levels. Conversely, Chad Morganlander of Washington Crossing Advisors is overweight financials, citing improving net interest margins, credit growth, declining loan loss provisions, and robust buybacks and dividend growth as reasons for optimism.

title: Ventas Closes $2.75B Credit Facility
summary: Ventas, Inc., a Chicago-based healthcare REIT, successfully closed a new four-year $2.75-billion unsecured credit facility, which was oversubscribed by 24 financial institutions. This facility enhances Ventas's liquidity, extends debt maturities, and improves borrowing costs, with nearly $2.7 billion of available borrowing capacity and a $1-billion accordion feature. BofA Securities and JPMorgan Chase Bank served as joint bookrunners.

title: Bank of America executive on how bank is drawing customers to digital services
summary: Bank of America's head of digital, David Tyrie, stated that the pandemic significantly accelerated the bank's digital banking goals. The article highlights BofA's success in attracting customers to its digital services, attributing this largely to changes brought about by the pandemic.

title: BofA’s Merrill Raises Margin to 100% to Trade Certain Stocks
summary: Bank of America Corp.'s Merrill Lynch raised margin requirements to 100% for wealth-management and self-directed brokerage clients to trade certain stocks. This move comes as financial firms impose limits amidst significant price volatility, which was sparked by investors on social media platforms. Typically, stock trading margins are around 30%, but these can fluctuate based on the concentration of client holdings.

title: Bank of America's Pittsburgh market president leaving
summary: Bank of America's Pittsburgh market president, Brian Ludwick, is leaving his current role to take on a new post in Houston, Texas. Ludwick was the first Pittsburgh market president for Bank of America, and a successor is expected to be named soon.

title: Bank of America's Pittsburgh market president taking role in Houston
summary: Brian Ludwick, who has been Bank of America's Pittsburgh market president since December 2017, is taking on a new role as market executive in Houston for the bank. This move was announced on January 28, 2021.

title: The LBO Value Equation
summary: This article explains the LBO value equation, detailing how private equity firms identify and value potential leveraged buyout targets. It outlines the characteristics that make a company attractive for an LBO, such as low leverage and stable cash flow, and illustrates the valuation process with real-world examples like Fidelity National Information Services. The content also provides a method for investors to spot potential LBO candidates and value the upside.

title: Bank of America sets aside $150M for minority financial institutions as part of previous $1B, four-year pledge
summary: Bank of America has allocated $150 million towards minority financial institutions, as part of a larger $1 billion, four-year commitment. This initiative aims to foster economic opportunity. The announcement provides more details on how the bank is deploying its previously announced pledge.

title: NCR and Cardtronics Announce Definitive Acquisition Agreement at $39.00 Per Share
summary: NCR Corporation has announced a definitive agreement to acquire Cardtronics for $39.00 per share in an all-cash transaction valued at approximately $2.5 billion, including debt. This acquisition aims to accelerate NCR's "NCR-as-a-Service" strategy, shift its revenue mix towards software, services, and recurring revenue, and expand opportunities in payments. The transaction is expected to be accretive to NCR's non-GAAP EPS in the first full year post-closing and is anticipated to generate $100-$120 million in run rate operating cost synergies by the end of 2022.

title: Obituary: PennyMac founder Stanford Kurland
summary: Stanford Kurland, founder of PennyMac Financial Services, passed away at age 68 from complications related to COVID-19 and brain cancer. Kurland had a significant impact on the mortgage industry, previously serving in key roles at Countrywide Financial before founding PennyMac, which grew to become a major player in residential mortgage lending and servicing.

title: Capital One Fined Millions for Ineffective Money-Laundering Protections
summary: Capital One was fined $390 million by FinCEN for willfully failing to maintain an effective anti-money laundering program, stemming from its dealings with high-risk check-cashing businesses from 2008 to 2014. Despite warnings and internal assessments, the bank failed to detect and report suspicious activities, including thousands of suspicious activity reports and over 50,000 currency transaction reports totaling more than $16 billion. Capital One has since paid the penalty, enhanced its AML program, and resolved the matter related to a now-defunct business unit.

title: Banks Fined for Price-Rigging
summary: Mexico's antitrust authority COFECE fined several major banks, including Barclays, Deutsche Bank, Santander, Citibanamex, Bank of America, BBVA, and JP Morgan, a total of over MX$35 million (US$1.74 million) for collusion on the peso bond market between 2010 and 2013. The fines concluded a four-year investigation that uncovered 142 illegal agreements to manipulate prices and negatively impacted the market by MX$29.39 million (US$1.46 million). Despite the penalties, the fines represent a fraction of what the banks could have faced, especially when compared to similar fines imposed by European and US regulators.

title: BofA’s Middle East Equities Head to Depart After Two Decades
summary: Talal Ghandour, Bank of America Corp.'s Dubai-based managing director and head of Middle East and North Africa equities, is departing the firm after 22 years. He plans to join his family business. Ali Hobballah will take over Ghandour's responsibilities for MENA equities.

title: NextDecade appoints a new chief financial officer
summary: NextDecade Corporation has announced the appointment of Brent E. Wahl as its new chief financial officer, effective February 1, 2021. Wahl, who previously served as senior vice president, finance at NextDecade and has over 20 years of experience in the energy industry, replaces Benjamin A. Atkins. The company's chairman and CEO, Matt Schatzman, expressed confidence that Wahl will play a key role in achieving a final investment decision for Rio Grande LNG in 2021.

title: Truist Financial posts higher fourth-quarter profits as merger-related work continues
