summary: Truist Financial Corp. reported solid fourth-quarter results, concluding its first full fiscal year with higher profits despite ongoing economic challenges. The bank continues its merger-related work, navigating a complex economic landscape.

title: Bank of America execs Moynihan, Donofrio look toward improvement after last year's profits dragged
summary: Bank of America executives Brian Moynihan and Paul Donofrio anticipate an improvement in the company's earnings in 2021 despite ongoing challenges posed by the pandemic. The bank, headquartered in Charlotte, is feeling confident about the upcoming year.

title: Bank of America beat analysts' income expectations in fourth quarter, missed on revenue
summary: Bank of America (BAC) exceeded analysts' income expectations but missed on revenue in its fourth-quarter 2020 earnings report, with pandemic headwinds continuing to impact results. Despite these challenges, the results suggest potential for recovery for the Charlotte-headquartered bank.

title: Investors flee Big Oil as portfolios get drilled
summary: The article details how Big Oil's financial might has been eroding for a decade, with a significant hit in 2020 due to collapsed fuel demand and oil prices. Investment firms and banks are increasingly wary of fossil fuels, with Goldman Sachs allocating more towards renewables, and major U.S. banks withdrawing funding for Arctic drilling. This shift is driven by both environmental concerns and the poor financial performance of the fossil fuel sector compared to growing competitive renewable energy.

title: Wells Fargo CEO to unveil cost-cutting plan
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Charlie Scharf is expected to unveil details of a long-awaited cost-cutting plan this week to investors. Despite an anticipated 38% profit decline, investor optimism regarding the strategic update has led to a significant jump in Wells Fargo's stock. This plan aims to transform the bank, which has been under scrutiny since its 2016 fraudulent account scandal.

Fargo CEO Charlie Scharf is expected to unveil details of a long-awaited cost-cutting plan this week to investors. Although Wells Fargo is projected to report a 38% profit decline due to the pandemic, investor excitement for the strategic update has driven a 45% increase in the bank's shares since October. This initiative aims to address lingering governance issues and overcome competitive disadvantages stemming from regulatory scrutiny and an asset cap placed on the bank.File Photo: Wells Fargo Bank branch is seen in New York City, U.S., March 17, 2020. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tab Companies Wells Fargo & Co Follow Jan 14 (Reuters) - Wells Fargo & Co (WFC.N) , opens new tab Chief Executive Charlie Scharf will give investors more details on his long-awaited turnaround plan for the scandal-plagued bank this week. Although Wall Street expects Wells Fargo to report a 38% profit decline on Friday against the backdrop of the coronavirus pandemic, investors have become more bullish in anticipation of details about expansive cost-cutting plans. Wells Fargo shares have jumped 45% since Scharf teased a strategic update in October, outperforming JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM.N) , opens new tab and Bank of America Corp (BAC.N) , opens new tab . read more Wells Fargo management has promised transformation since its 2016 fraudulent account scandal with little to show for the effort, but it feels different now, Raymond James analyst David Long said. Scharf's "really changed the internal attitude to make improving the bank's governance the number one priority," Long said. Scharf started making changes shortly after taking the helm in October 2019, though he has not yet provided firm targets or timelines for progress. He installed a slew of external leaders, overhauled the reporting segments, and began to shed non-core businesses. He also implemented weekly and monthly reviews to increase oversight and address regulator concerns more efficiently. read more In a sign of progress repairing Wells Fargo's relationship with regulators, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency ended a consent order related to anti-money laundering compliance on the bank earlier this month. read more But Wells' largest hurdles remain and it has a long way to go to catch up with peers. Efficiency ratios across Wells' largest business lines dramatically lag other big banks. Further, the ongoing need for spending to satisfy regulators and the presence of punitive asset cap until Wells proves it fixed the risk management failures that led to the widespread customer abuses will continue to hinder the bank's ability to compete effectively. "Other banks have not been operating under these consent orders so they've been able to spend a good amount of their mindshare thinking about operating efficiency and the future," Long said. "Wells has not." Reporting by Imani Moise; Editing by Leslie Adler Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tab

title: Anchorage Becomes First OCC-Approved National Crypto Bank
authors: Nikhilesh De and Ian Allison for CoinDesk
summary: Crypto custodian Anchorage has secured conditional approval for a national trust charter from the U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC), making it the first national "digital asset bank" in the U.S. This approval grants Anchorage the ability to operate nationwide, bypassing the need for multiple state licenses, and enables it to offer crypto services like lending and staking directly connected to the financial system. The move is seen as a significant step towards the modernization of financial services and brings crypto companies closer to the traditional banking world.

title: Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, JPMorgan to pause political donations
authors: Yueqi Yang and Sridhar Natarajan and Bloomberg
summary: Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase & Co. announced they would pause political contributions following the Capitol riots, joining a growing list of companies reviewing their donation policies. JPMorgan plans a six-month suspension to both parties, while Citigroup will temporarily stop all contributions in the current quarter. Other companies like Marriott International, Blue Cross Blue Shield Association, and Commerce Bank have also suspended donations, particularly to senators who opposed the certification of the 2020 election results.

title: Uptown tower renamed, renovations planned after Bank of America's exit
summary: Cousins Properties has rebranded the former Bank of America Plaza at Trade and Tryon streets as One South at the Plaza, following Bank of America's departure. The company has plans to renovate the uptown tower. This change comes after Bank of America exited its space in the building.

title: Telus International takes first step toward IPO
summary: Telus International, the international unit of Telus Corp., has filed a registration statement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering. The company plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange and the Toronto Stock Exchange, with the number of shares and price range yet to be determined. This move follows Telus's previous announcements in 2019 about taking the unit public and recent acquisitions to expand its services.

title: Already Up 35% in 2021, the DPST ETF Isn't Messing Around
summary: The Direxion Daily Regional Banks Bull 3X Shares (DPST) ETF has surged 35% in early 2021, reflecting a strong start for regional banking stocks after a challenging 2020. Analysts are optimistic, with upgrades for companies like Fifth Third Bancorp, despite ongoing low-interest rate concerns. DPST, which seeks 300% daily performance of the S&P Regional Banks Select Industry Index, is showing signs of recovery and has gained over 170% in the last three months.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America's first-quarter profit doubled to $8.05 billion, significantly exceeding the $4.01 billion reported a year prior. This increase was largely due to the release of reserves that had been set aside for potential bad loans during the pandemic. Despite the strong profit growth, the bank's revenue remained flat.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America reported that its first-quarter profit doubled to $8.05 billion after releasing money previously earmarked for potential bad loans. This performance beat analysts' expectations, though revenue remained flat. The move comes as the bank, like others, had significantly increased its reserves at the beginning of the pandemic.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America reported a doubling of its profit in the first quarter of the year, reaching $8.05 billion, largely due to releasing money previously set aside for potential bad loans. This marks a significant increase from $4.01 billion recorded in the same period last year when banks were stockpiling reserves due to the pandemic. The first-quarter results surpassed analysts' expectations.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America's first-quarter profit doubled to $8.05 billion after it released $2.7 billion in reserves previously set aside for bad loans, significantly beating analysts' expectations. This move, similar to those by JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Wells Fargo & Co., reflects increased optimism about an economic rebound. Despite higher trading revenue and investment banking fees boosting earnings, increased noninterest expenses, including one-time costs, led to a 2.9% drop in Bank of America's stock.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America announced its profit doubled in the first quarter of the year, reaching $8.05 billion, largely due to releasing reserves previously set aside for potential bad loans. This marks a significant increase from $4.01 billion in the same period last year when banks were stockpiling reserves due to the pandemic. The results surpassed analysts' expectations, even though the bank's revenue remained flat.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America announced its first-quarter profit doubled to $8.05 billion after releasing reserves previously set aside for potential bad loans. This significant increase from $4.01 billion a year earlier reflects a trend among lenders benefiting from stronger economic conditions and reduced fears of widespread defaults due to the pandemic. Despite the soaring profit, the bank's revenue remained flat.

title: Stock Pickers Built These ETFs to Be More Nimble. They’re Off to a Slow Start. - WSJ
summary: New semitransparent active ETFs, designed to be more nimble and offer cheaper alternatives to mutual funds, are facing a slow rollout despite their innovative features. Major brokerages like Bank of America, UBS, and Wells Fargo are hesitant to offer them to wealth-management clients, citing the need for further scrutiny and long-term performance data. This hesitation from key financial institutions is hindering the broader adoption and access to these new funds.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America announced a significant increase in its first-quarter profit, doubling to $8.05 billion, primarily due to the release of reserves held against potential bad loans. This move reflects a broader trend among lenders to decrease their pandemic-driven stockpiling of rainy-day reserves. Despite beating analysts' expectations, the bank's revenue remained flat.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America reported a doubling of its profit in the first quarter of the year, reaching $8.05 billion, primarily due to the release of reserves set aside for potential bad loans. This performance beat analysts' expectations, though the bank's revenue remained flat. The move follows similar actions by other lenders who had bulked up reserves at the onset of the pandemic.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America's first-quarter profit doubled to $8.05 billion, largely due to releasing $2.7 billion in reserves previously set aside for potential loan losses. This beat analysts' expectations and reflects increased optimism for an economic rebound, similar to other major banks. Despite increased trading revenue and investment banking fees, noninterest expenses jumped, causing Bank of America's shares to fall while the S&P 500 rose.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America reported a doubled profit in the first quarter, reaching $8.05 billion, largely due to releasing reserves previously set aside for potential bad loans. This performance beat analysts' expectations, though the bank's revenue remained flat. This trend follows other lenders who are adjusting their financial positions as economic conditions shift from the initial pandemic-driven uncertainty.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America's first-quarter profit doubled to $8.05 billion after it released reserves previously set aside for bad loans. This significant increase from $4.01 billion the prior year reflects global lenders benefiting from the improving economic outlook, allowing them to reverse some of their pandemic-era provisions. The results surpassed analysts' expectations, despite revenue remaining flat.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America significantly increased its first-quarter profit to $8.05 billion after releasing reserves previously set aside for potential bad loans. This marks a doubling of profit compared to the previous year, surpassing analysts' expectations, despite revenue remaining flat. The move follows a trend among other lenders who had bulked up reserves early in the pandemic.

title: Bank of America’s Merrill Lynch to Ban Trainee Brokers From Making Cold Calls - WSJ
summary: Merrill Lynch Wealth Management is banning its trainee brokers from making cold calls, a significant shift from a long-standing industry practice. Instead, new recruits will be directed to use internal referrals and LinkedIn messages to find clients. This decision follows issues last year with outbound recruiting efforts by the program's 3,000 trainees.

title: Bank of America Profit Doubles After It Releases Reserves for Bad Loans
summary: Bank of America announced a doubling of its profit in the first quarter of the year, driven by the release of reserves previously set aside for bad loans. The Charlotte, N.C.-based lender reported earnings of $8.05 billion, significantly up from $4.01 billion in the same period last year. This increase follows a trend among other lenders who are adjusting their pandemic-era financial provisions.

title: Merrill Loses $2.8-Mln Producer to UBS, $2-Mln Team to Independence
summary: Merrill Lynch lost a $2.8 million producer to UBS Wealth Management USA in Louisiana and a $2 million team to Raymond James Financial's independent broker channel in New Jersey. The advisors cited frustration with Merrill's cross-selling mandates and annual account-growth targets tied to compensation. This move reflects a broader trend of advisors leaving Merrill and other wirehouses due to evolving business models.

title: STI highlights from 2020
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) experienced an 8% decline in 2020 through December 2nd, but its Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) saw significant growth, with combined assets under management (AUM) nearly doubling to S$2.08 billion. This growth was driven by increased investor participation, especially in the June and September quarters. The article also highlights the impact of new joiners like Keppel DC Reit and Mapletree Industrial Trust, and the cornerstone role of local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, despite their initial declines.

title: Euronet Worldwide acquires BoI’s non-branch ATM fleet
summary: Euronet Worldwide Inc. has acquired Bank of Ireland's fleet of 700 non-branch ATMs in the Republic of Ireland, with the transfer of ownership set for February 28, 2021. Euronet will manage and upgrade the acquired network, rebranding it and integrating it with its existing ATMs in the region. This acquisition is part of Euronet's strategy to consolidate ATMs and expand product offerings, proving its role as a catalyst in ATM consolidation.

title: Wells Fargo hires former Bank of America executive Michelle Moore for digital banking role - Bizwomen
summary: Wells Fargo has hired former Bank of America executive Michelle Moore as its digital platform leader, effective December 31st. Moore will report to Ather Williams III and will be based in Charlotte, focusing on digital banking strategy and "digital experiences" within the consumer banking business. This hire aligns with Wells Fargo's emphasis on digital banking to reduce annual costs and build out a digital-first retail concept.

title: Vanguard makes history with first $1 trillion equity fund
summary: Vanguard's Total Stock Market Index Fund has become the first equity fund to surpass $1 trillion in assets, highlighting the growth of index-based investing. This milestone is attributed to rising U.S. stocks, falling fees, and increased investor education on fund fees and active management underperformance. The fund, which includes both a mutual fund and an ETF, was created in 1992 and the ETF has seen significant inflows.

title: 4D Molecular Therapeutics Announces Closing of Initial Public Offering and Full Exercise of Underwriters’ Option to Purchase Additional Shares
summary: 4D Molecular Therapeutics, Inc. announced the closing of its initial public offering, raising approximately $222 million, including the full exercise of the underwriters' option to purchase additional shares. The shares began trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the ticker symbol “FDMT.” The company, a clinical-stage gene therapy firm, is focused on developing product candidates using targeted and evolved AAV vectors in ophthalmology, cardiology, and pulmonology.

title: BNY Mellon Wealth Management Announces Laura Kaplan as Market President in Miami, FL
summary: BNY Mellon Wealth Management has appointed Laura Kaplan as Market President in Miami, FL, to lead the region's wealth management practice. Kaplan, with extensive experience from Bank of America Private Bank, Deutsche Bank, and Citi Private Bank, will oversee client strategists, wealth managers, and support staff, reporting to Southeast President Kent Moegerle. This appointment aims to strengthen BNY Mellon's offerings for ultra-high-net-worth individuals and families in the Southeast market.

title: Huntington and TCF Financial to merge in $22 billion deal
summary: Huntington Bancshares and TCF Financial Corp. are merging in an all-stock deal valued at $22 billion, creating a regional bank expected to rank in the top 10 nationally. The Huntington brand will survive, and the combined company will maintain dual headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, and Detroit, with a significant commitment to Michigan including jobs and community investments. The merger is expected to close in the second quarter and result in approximately $490 million in cost savings.

title: Deal of the Year: American Express buys Kabbage
summary: American Express acquired Kabbage's team, fintech products, data platform, and internet protocol for small businesses in a deal estimated between $750 million and $1 billion. This acquisition highlights both companies' strategies to expand beyond their traditional services, with Kabbage moving beyond lending into checking accounts and AmEx aiming to strengthen its small-business offerings and become more essential to its customers. The move by American Express follows similar acquisitions by Visa and Mastercard, demonstrating a broader trend in the payments industry to integrate data aggregation and expand services.

title: Seer Announces Closing of Initial Public Offering and Full
summary: Seer, Inc. announced the closing of its initial public offering, raising approximately $201.3 million gross proceeds. The offering included the full exercise of underwriters' option to purchase additional shares, totaling 10,592,106 shares of Class A common stock at $19.00 per share. Seer's Class A common stock began trading on Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "SEER" on December 4, 2020.

title: Bank of Butterfield appoints Sonia Baxendale to its board
summary: The Bank of N.T. Butterfield & Son has appointed Sonia Baxendale to its board as an independent director. Baxendale brings extensive experience from her role as president and CEO of the Global Risk Institute and previous senior leadership positions in retail banking and wealth management at CIBC. Her appointment coincides with Leslie Godridge's departure and is expected to provide invaluable insight into emerging risk factors affecting the global financial services industry.

title: Fifth Third Bank plots next branch in Charlotte amid fast-paced retail expansion
summary: Fifth Third Bancorp is planning to open another retail branch in Charlotte, continuing its rapid expansion in the region. This news comes as the bank has been actively growing its presence in the Charlotte market, a strategy that has been highlighted by its CEO. The ongoing expansion indicates a significant focus on retail banking growth in the area.

title: NISN - NiSun International Enterprise Development Group Co Ltd Stock Price and Quote
summary: This article provides a stock price quote and financial data for NiSun International Enterprise Development Group Co Ltd (NISN), including market capitalization, insider ownership, and performance metrics. It also lists recent news releases and operational updates detailing the company's expansion into various sectors like edible oil trading, corn supply, and gold business.

title: Banker Jorge Brito killed in Salta helicopter crash
summary: Argentine banker, businessman, and entrepreneur Jorge Brito, 68, was killed in a helicopter crash in Salta, Argentina, along with his pilot. The accident is believed to have occurred when the helicopter, flown by Brito, collided with a zip line owned by a local tourist company. Brito was known for founding Banco Macro and his extensive business interests, and was among Argentina's wealthiest individuals.

title: Desglobalización bancaria
summary: BBVA's strategic move to sell its US operations and propose a merger with Banco Sabadell signifies a shift towards "desglobalización" and a "back to basics" approach, focusing on its traditional Spanish market. This strategy aims to improve solvency and achieve synergies to counter low banking profitability in Spain and Europe, despite increasing market concentration. The article also notes that while national market share will rise, competition in sub-markets and from non-bank digital entities will mitigate potential negative effects.

title: Hawaiian Airlines, Barclays, CPI Card Group, Collaborate on Recovered Ocean-Bound Plastic Credit Cards
summary: Hawaiian Airlines and Barclays US Consumer Bank have partnered with CPI Card Group to introduce Second Wave™ credit cards made with recovered ocean-bound plastic for its Hawaiian Airlines World Elite Mastercard® members. This initiative aims to address plastic waste in oceans, with CPI estimating that over one ton of plastic will be diverted for every one million cards produced. To further support coastal stewardship, Hawaiian Airlines and Barclays are contributing $50,000 to Sustainable Coastlines Hawai‘i.

title: Think Private Prison Companies Are Going Away Under Biden? They Have Other Plans
summary: Despite the election of Joe Biden, who pledged to curb private prisons, major companies like CoreCivic and GEO Group are well-positioned to continue profiting. They have been aggressively diversifying their business models, shifting away from traditional prisons towards other government contracts such as commercial real estate, electronic monitoring, and halfway houses, and capitalizing on growing needs for immigration detention and re-entry services. This strategic pivot ensures their financial stability even as the political climate changes regarding mass incarceration.

title: PNC buys Houston-based BBVA USA for $11.6 billion
summary: PNC Financial Services Group has agreed to acquire BBVA's Houston-based U.S. banking operations for $11.6 billion, positioning it to become the country's largest regional bank. This acquisition allows PNC to expand into Texas and California, using funds from its BlackRock Inc. stake sale, while providing BBVA with capital for potential acquisitions and an exit from a business that has weighed on its earnings. The deal, expected to close by June, will boost PNC's earnings and significantly expand its presence across the southern and southwestern U.S.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | PNC Financial Services to Buy U.S. Arm of Spain’s BBVA for $11.6 Billion
summary: PNC Financial Services Group Inc. has agreed to acquire the U.S. operations of Spain's BBVA for $11.6 billion. This deal marks one of the largest bank mergers since the financial crisis, poised to establish the fifth-largest U.S. retail bank with over $550 billion in assets.

title: BBVA sells U.S. subsidiary to PNC for $11.6 billion
summary: BBVA has agreed to sell its U.S. subsidiary to PNC for $11.6 billion in cash, a transaction that will significantly enhance BBVA's financial position and provide flexibility for capital deployment and shareholder distributions. The deal, valued at 19.7 times the unit's 2019 earnings, excludes BBVA's broker dealer and New York branch, allowing BBVA to continue serving corporate and institutional clients in the U.S. PNC will become the fifth-largest bank in the U.S. by assets after the transaction closes, which is expected in mid-2021.

title: Banco Santander Is Reportedly Planning to Shut Down Up to 1,000 Branches, May Cut 4,000 Jobs
summary: Banco Santander is reportedly planning significant cost-cutting measures in Spain, including the closure of up to 1,000 branches and the elimination of 4,000 jobs. These actions are a response to economic challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, low interest rates in the euro zone, and a growing consumer shift to digital banking. The bank, along with other European lenders, is struggling to adapt to these market changes and maintain operational efficiency.

title: Irsa y Cresud: contundente apoyo al canje de sus ON
summary: IRSA and Cresud successfully concluded their debt exchange offers, receiving strong support from investors. IRSA achieved a 98.31% acceptance rate for its bonds totaling US$178 million, while Cresud saw an 88.41% acceptance for US$65 million. The exchange involved the issuance of new series of negotiable obligations with varying maturity dates, enabling the companies to navigate restrictions imposed by the BCRA on foreign currency debt payments.
source: El Economista: Últimas noticias económicas y financieras
source_domain: El Economista: Últimas noticias económicas y financieras

title: Arbor Realty Names Affordable Housing Managing Director
summary: Arbor Realty Trust Inc. has appointed Arthanais Williams as managing director of affordable housing, where he will oversee the agency's multifamily affordable financing platform and structured product lines. Williams brings over 20 years of experience from previous roles at Freddie Mac and Bank of America Merrill Lynch, specializing in valuation, acquisition, rehabilitation, and financial structuring for various real estate assets.

title: Wirehouse Wars: Merrill Loses Young NYC Star to Morgan Stanley
summary: James P Taylor, a young and highly-regarded Merrill Lynch advisor who built a significant book of business, moved his 13-person team to Morgan Stanley. This move highlights an ongoing trend of Merrill losing seasoned and next-gen advisors, despite the firm's efforts to retain talent through new career-development programs amid its recruiting freeze. Taylor's team, specializing in corporate executive stock portfolios, represents a significant gain for Morgan Stanley, which has actively recruited teams in this niche.

title: Sallie Mae lays off 100+ in Delaware in restructuring
summary: Sallie Mae laid off 105 employees in Delaware as part of a company-wide restructuring to cut costs and boost operating efficiencies amid a disrupted higher education market. The layoffs represent 6% of the company's total workforce and incurred $24 million in restructuring expenses, primarily for severance and benefits. Despite the cuts, Sallie Mae is actively hiring in Delaware and its CEO stated the restructuring is to align the business with strategic imperatives and strengthen the company for 2021.

title: Biden Basket Vs Trump Trade — Potential Stock and Sector Winners and Losers
summary: This article explores potential stock and sector winners and losers under a Biden administration versus a second Trump term, based on analyses from financial institutions. It identifies "Biden basket" stocks in alternative energy, infrastructure, and those benefiting from fiscal stimulus and reduced tariff tensions, while "Trump basket" stocks include banks, fossil fuel companies, big tech, defense, and pharma/biotech due to differing regulatory and policy approaches.

title: American Express pledges $1B toward racial, gender equality
summary: American Express has committed $1 billion to advance racial and gender equality, with a significant portion dedicated to doubling spending with diverse and minority-owned suppliers to $750 million annually by 2024. The company also announced it achieved 100% gender pay equity worldwide and aims to support Black-owned businesses, female entrepreneurs, and non-profit organizations led by underrepresented groups. This pledge follows similar commitments from other financial institutions in response to recent social justice movements.

title: Citigroup issues largest-ever private sector social bond
summary: Citigroup has issued the largest-ever private-sector social bond, a $2.5 billion issuance aimed at affordable housing as part of a broader $1 billion initiative to combat racial inequality. This transaction contributes to a surge in social bond issuances during the coronavirus pandemic, with proceeds channeled to socially beneficial projects, mirroring similar efforts by banks like Bank of America. The move reinforces Citi's commitment to increasing homeownership among racial minorities and reflects growing interest in ethical investments.

title: This Bank Wants to Use Animal Crossing to Sell You on Financial Services
summary: Ally, a financial services company, hosted a sponsored island in Animal Crossing to market its banking and investment services to millennials. The campaign aimed to connect with a demographic less engaged with traditional banking by showcasing financial products within the game's context, emphasizing wealth management and investing as easy and accessible. The article critiques this marketing approach as a manifestation of the financialization of games and the gamification of finance, aiming to define how millennial consumers "should" act in a capitalistic system.

title: Carver Selected for Bank of America Investment
summary: Bank of America has made equity investments in ten minority depository institutions as part of its $1 billion commitment to racial equality and economic opportunity. Carver Financial Corporation, holding company for Carver State Bank of Savannah, is among the institutions to receive an investment. These investments, totaling approximately 4.9% of the common equity in each organization, aim to scale critical projects and enable positive change within communities served by these MDIs and CDFIs.

title: Texas Capital Bancshares names JPMorgan executive Rob Holmes as its new CEO
summary: Texas Capital Bancshares has appointed Rob C. Holmes, a JPMorgan Chase & Co. executive, as its new Chief Executive Officer, effective January 2021. Holmes will replace Larry L. Helm, who took on the role after a proposed $5.5 billion merger with Independent Bank fell apart earlier in the year. The Dallas-based bank struggled earlier in 2020 but saw a turnaround in the third quarter after Helm took over.

title: Dave & Buster’s Announces Closing of $550 Million Senior Secured Notes Offering by its Subsidiary Dave & Buster’s, Inc.
summary: Dave & Buster's Entertainment, Inc. announced the closing of a $550 million senior secured notes offering by its subsidiary, Dave & Buster's, Inc. The proceeds from the 7.625% senior secured notes due 2025 will be used to repay outstanding amounts under its Term Loan Facility and drawings under its Revolving Credit Facility. J.P. Morgan acted as lead book running manager for the private offering.

title: Shinhan closing in on HSBC to be top foreign bank in Vietnam
summary: Shinhan Bank Vietnam is on track to become the leading foreign bank in Vietnam, driven by strong performance, advanced digital services, and an aggressive localization strategy. The bank's net profit saw significant growth despite the global pandemic, placing it in fierce competition with HSBC Vietnam. Shinhan's focus on retail banking services, expansion of its network, and support for Korean SMEs in Vietnam have been key factors in its success.
source: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition
source_domain: The Korea Economic Daily Global Edition

title: Does Capital One Offer Student Loans?
summary: Capital One does not offer student loans, prompting individuals to seek alternatives for private student loans or refinancing. The article suggests exploring options from other banks, credit unions, online lenders like Ascent, College Ave, and Earnest, and state-based agencies. It also emphasizes exhausting federal financial aid opportunities before considering private loans due to their unique benefits.

title: Wells Fargo to Eliminate 401(k) Match for High-Paid Employees–Sources
summary: Wells Fargo & Co. is eliminating the 401(k) retirement account match for employees earning $250,000 or higher, as part of its expense reduction efforts. The bank aims to emphasize support for lower-paid employees and will introduce new efforts to seed retirement plans for those making less than $75,000 annually. Despite not anticipating significant savings from this change, it represents a broader measure taken by the bank to address financial pressures and past scandals.

title: Essent increases credit facility
summary: Essent Group Ltd has increased its credit facility from $500 million to $625 million, which includes an increase in its revolving credit facility and an additional non-amortising term loan. This move enhances the Bermudian-based mortgage re/insurer's capital and liquidity position, with borrowings available for working capital and general corporate purposes. The amended terms and extended maturity to October 2023 reflect Essent's strong financial profile and provide added financial flexibility.

title: Is Charles Schwab Still Active in the Company?
summary: Charles Schwab Corporation is a significant entity in financial services, founded by Charles Robert Schwab in 1971. The article explains Charles Schwab's personal history, how his company revolutionized investing through discount brokerage services, and its current offerings including banking and asset management. Charles Schwab himself remains active as the company's chairman and largest shareholder, with an estimated net worth of $7.4 billion.

title: Who is Truist CEO Kelly King? He’s not the banker you think he is
summary: This article profiles Truist CEO Kelly King, detailing his journey from poverty in rural North Carolina to leading the sixth-largest bank in the U.S. It highlights his pivotal role in the $66 billion merger of BB&T and SunTrust, emphasizing how his challenging upbringing shaped his leadership style and resilience in the banking industry. The story explores his personal transformation after a behavioral psychology retreat and his commitment to overcoming challenges, drawing parallels between his past struggles and his current leadership role.

title: 'FinCEN Files' leaker harmed US anti-laundering regime and should be prosecuted, say bankers
summary: Bank compliance officers are calling for the prosecution of the individual responsible for leaking over 2,000 highly confidential suspicious activity reports (SARs) that led to the "FinCEN Files" news articles. They argue that the leak undermines trust in the SARs system, which is crucial for the U.S. fight against illicit financial transactions, and necessitates re-evaluation of how banks file these sensitive documents to maintain partnerships with law enforcement. Authorities are investigating the source of the leak, which has raised concerns about the efficacy and future of the anti-money laundering regime.

title: Peloton Has Soared 350% In 2020. Here’s Why The Stock Will Keep Rising This Year, According To Experts
summary: Peloton shares reached an all-time high despite a recall and patent infringement suit, with analysts predicting further growth. Experts suggest that a permanent shift towards at-home fitness due to the pandemic will continue to drive Peloton's success, with several analysts raising their price targets. The company's stock has quadrupled since May, driven by strong quarterly earnings reports and increased investor optimism.

title: Wells Fargo cuts 'sizable group' of advisers after profits slump
summary: Wells Fargo is laying off a "sizable group" of financial advisers, particularly those in the Financial Relationship Advisors group, as part of a cost-cutting effort due to slumping profits and the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank reported a year-over-year decline of 815 advisers, a 5.9% drop, bringing its total to 12,908 advisers. This move is significant given the rarity of adviser layoffs in the wealth management industry where they are crucial for revenue generation.

title: Bank of America Profit Falls 16%
summary: Bank of America's profit fell 16% in the third quarter to $4.88 billion, down from $5.78 billion a year ago. Despite the drop, the bank stated it is well-prepared to handle the coronavirus recession. This earnings report was part of a series of bank reports highlighting financial performance during the pandemic.

title: Goldman’s Pandemic Hot Streak Continues in Third Quarter
summary: Goldman Sachs reported a near-doubling of its third-quarter profit, reaching $3.62 billion on revenue of $10.78 billion, significantly exceeding analyst forecasts despite the ongoing pandemic and recession. This strong performance, driven by trading revenue increases, highlights Wall Street's continued profitability amidst broader economic challenges. While banks' "Main Street" arms also show resilience, concerns about a potential double-dip recession and prolonged high unemployment remain.

title: Bank of America Profit Falls 16%
summary: Bank of America's third-quarter profit declined by 16% to $4.88 billion compared to the previous year, although the bank stated it is prepared to handle the coronavirus recession. This comes after earning $3.53 billion in the prior quarter. The Charlotte, N.C., lender announced these figures from July to September.

title: Goldman's trading business returns to former glory during pandemic stress
summary: Goldman Sachs reported its best quarterly performance in a decade, largely driven by a 29% jump in trading revenue during the pandemic. The bank's limited exposure to consumer lending, unlike its rivals, proved to be an advantage. Analysts consider its current business mix, with strong capital markets leverage and a small, high-quality loan portfolio, to be well-suited for the current economic climate.

title: Americold Acquires Agro Merchants Group In $1.74 Billion Deal
summary: Americold Realty Trust (NYSE: COLD) has announced the acquisition of Agro Merchants Group, the world's fourth-largest temperature-controlled operator, for $1.74 billion. This strategic move aims to expand Americold's global network, particularly facilitating its entry into Europe and strengthening its presence in the U.S., South America, and Australia. The deal, expected to close late 2020 or early 2021, will result in Americold's portfolio comprising 229 owned and managed facilities globally.

title: Eastern Bank Prepares for $1.8B IPO
summary: Eastern Bank, the oldest mutual bank in the US, is set to go public on the Nasdaq Global Select Market on October 14, with shares launching at $10 each, valuing the company at nearly $1.8 billion. The capital raised from the IPO will be used for technology investments, new services, and acquisitions in banking and insurance. Additionally, former CEO Ken LaRoe announced plans to launch Climate First Bank in Florida, focusing on an impact-based "triple bottom line" approach.

title: China’s Ping An-Backed Lufax Files for $3 Billion U.S. IPO
summary: Lufax Holding Ltd., a Chinese online wealth management platform backed by Ping An Insurance Group, has filed for a U.S. IPO aiming to raise about $3 billion. This move comes as the company shifts away from its P2P lending origins and follows another Ping An-backed fintech listing (OneConnect Financial Technology), amidst a backdrop of rising U.S.-China tensions. The company reported a net profit of 7.27 billion yuan for the first half of 2020.

title: Actualización: Cemex recauda fondos en emisión internacional para pagar deuda
summary: Cemex, a Mexican cement company, issued $1 billion in senior guaranteed notes in the international market at a 5.200% rate with a 10-year term to pay down debt and for general corporate purposes. This private placement, which closed on September 17, involved several legal advisors for Cemex and the initial purchasers. The company plans to list these notes on the Irish Stock Exchange for trading on Euronext Dublin, following a similar bond issue in June.

title: Morgan Stanley’s Eaton Vance Acquisition Could Mean More Asset Management Mergers Are Coming
summary: Morgan Stanley is acquiring asset management firm Eaton Vance for $7 billion, increasing its assets under management to $1.2 trillion and solidifying a trend of consolidation in the asset management industry. Analysts believe more mergers are likely as firms seek to fill product gaps and benefit from historically low valuations. This acquisition follows Morgan Stanley's earlier purchase of E-Trade, indicating a strategic shift towards expanding its investment management business.

title: Bank of America wades into digital financial planning space
summary: Bank of America is launching "Life Plan," a new digital financial planning tool to compete with fintech companies. This tool allows customers to set financial goals and receive personalized recommendations by leveraging existing client data, making financial planning accessible beyond high-net worth individuals. The initiative aims to provide a fuller financial picture to customers and potentially increase engagement with the bank's services.

title: Lightsource bp Secures Financing on Bighorn Solar Project in Colorado
summary: Lightsource bp has secured $285 million in financing for its Bighorn Solar project in Pueblo, Colorado. The project, located on the Evraz Rocky Mountain Steel mill property, will supply power to the steel mill via a long-term contract with Xcel Energy, helping to preserve 1,000 local jobs and support Colorado's renewable energy goals. Construction has begun and is expected to create 300 direct jobs, with commercial operation slated for late 2021.

title: USAA sues PNC over alleged infringement of mobile deposit tech
summary: USAA has sued PNC in federal court, alleging that PNC infringed on two patents related to mobile check deposit technology. This lawsuit follows USAA's prior nine-figure judgments against Wells Fargo for similar patent infringements. USAA seeks reasonable compensation for the use of its remote deposit capture patents, which are also used by over 6,500 financial institutions that utilize Mitek Systems' technology.

title: KKR-backed Academy Sports and Outdoors raises $203 million in IPO - source
summary: Academy Sports and Outdoors, backed by KKR, raised $203 million in its IPO by selling shares at $13 each, below its target range of $15-$17. The IPO valued the company at $1.1 billion, despite a surge in demand for at-home leisure activities during the coronavirus pandemic which significantly boosted its e-commerce sales. Shares are expected to begin trading on Nasdaq under the symbol "ASO".

title: As Goldman, JPMorgan resume cuts, Bank of America reiterates no-layoff vow
summary: As Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase resume job cuts, Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan reiterated the bank's commitment to no layoffs for the year. This comes as other major banks like Citi and Wells Fargo have also restarted workforce reductions, with the industry on pace to cut over 80,000 positions in 2020. Moynihan highlighted Bank of America's strategy of relying on attrition and its progress in diversity initiatives.

title: Lithia Announces Pricing of Public Offering of Common Stock
summary: Lithia Motors, Inc. announced the pricing of its public offering of 3,181,819 shares of Class A common stock at $220.00 per share, with an option for underwriters to purchase additional shares. Concurrently, Lithia announced a private offering of $550 million aggregate principal amount of 4.375% senior notes due 2031, an increase from the previously announced size. The offering is expected to close on October 5, 2020.

title: Goldman Sachs to go ahead with "modest" job cuts after coronavirus pause
summary: Goldman Sachs Group Inc plans to proceed with a "modest number of layoffs" after pausing job cuts due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The bank is reportedly looking to cut about 400 jobs, or roughly 1% of its workforce, primarily targeting back-office roles as part of an earlier reorganisation aimed at improving efficiency. This comes as the U.S. Federal Reserve curbed big bank capital distributions through the end of the year, affecting share buybacks and dividends for major banks.

title: IRSA buscará reestructurar su deuda en dólares
summary: IRSA will present a proposal to its creditors to restructure its debt of US$181 million, which matures on November 15, adhering to BCRA regulations. This comes as the BCRA has called on companies with foreign currency debt exceeding US$1 million monthly to present restructuring plans. The proposal must include a maximum 40% access to the exchange market and a two-year extension for the remaining payments.

title: Truist, BofA among banks with largest Orlando market share
summary: The article discusses how Truist and Bank of America hold the largest banking market shares in metro Orlando. The merger of BB&T and SunTrust was a key factor in establishing Truist as one of the largest banks in the market. The content highlights the competitive landscape of the banking sector in the Orlando area.

title: PNC opens first retail branch in Greater Boston
summary: PNC Bank has opened its first retail branch in Greater Boston, located at 55 Boylston St. in Chestnut Hill. This is the first of five planned locations for the Pittsburgh-based banking giant in the region for 2020, signaling an expansion into the Boston market.

title: Two locals make annual list of top performing U.S. small-cap banks and thrifts
summary: Two local banks, Meridian and Parke, have been named to investment firm Piper Sandler’s annual list of top-performing U.S. small-cap banks and thrifts. This exclusive list includes only 35 U.S. banks with a market cap below $2.5 billion that meet rigorous criteria related to growth, profitability, credit quality, and capital strength.

title: Goldman Sachs names new heads of global M&A
summary: Goldman Sachs has appointed Stephan Feldgoise and Mark Sorrell as co-heads of its global mergers and acquisitions practice. They succeed Michael Carr, Dusty Philip, and Gilberto Pozzi, who will now serve as co-chairs of the bank’s global M&A unit. The appointments come as global deal volumes are down almost 40% year-to-date, despite a recent uptick in activity.

title: Old-School Regions Bank Lobby Set to Close
summary: Regions Bank is closing the lobby of its two-story branch at 400 W. Capitol Ave. in Little Rock, effective November 6th, and relocating branch operations to the second floor of the same building. This move signifies the end of another spacious old-school bank lobby, following a similar downsizing by Bank of America in 2018. The bank, headquartered in Birmingham, Alabama, reported a second-quarter loss of $214 million, primarily due to an $882 million increase in its provision for potential losses.

title: Bank with the largest market share in Atlanta changes for the first time since 2005
summary: Bank of America has taken the top spot for the largest market share of deposits in the metro Atlanta area in 2020, marking the first change since 2005. This shift was revealed by newly released data from the FDIC and reflects the impact of recent mergers and acquisitions within the banking industry.

title: Morgan Stanley Narrows Recruiting-Attrition Gap, Hires $5 Mln UBS Duo
summary: Morgan Stanley is close to reversing its net outflow of financial advisors, with CFO Jon Pruzan highlighting that net recruiting is now "much closer to zero." The firm recently hired a $4.8 million producing duo from UBS, Gerald Crum and Darren Hugo, as part of its selective re-entry into the recruiting market. This increased focus on recruiting high-producing advisors aims to make Morgan Stanley a "destination of choice" for financial advisors again.

title: Why are bank branches gobbling up Charlotte’s hottest real estate?
summary: Despite a national trend of bank branch closures since the recession and increased digital banking, new bank branches, including Fifth Third Bank and JPMorgan Chase, are rapidly opening in Charlotte's fast-growing and expensive neighborhoods. Banks view these high-tech, modern branches as crucial for connecting with customers, building loyalty, and attracting newcomers to the competitive Charlotte banking market even as they acknowledge a shift towards digital transactions for basic needs. The article also notes how even Bank of America and Wells Fargo are adapting their physical presence, with BofA modernizing existing centers and Wells Fargo opening "digital-first" Express Centers.

title: CEO Kelly King talks Truist Financial's strategy for merger-related cost cuts
summary: Truist Financial Corp. CEO Kelly King discusses the company's strategy for achieving cost cuts related to its merger. The financial institution is nearing the end of its first year post-merger and is focused on optimizing expenses.

title: ‘It has to have an impact’: What Citi’s new CEO means for other women on Wall Street
summary: Jane Fraser's appointment as CEO of Citigroup marks a historic milestone as the first woman to lead a major Wall Street bank, sparking optimism about the future for other senior women in finance. This promotion, while significant, highlights that increasing female representation in top executive roles is a slow process requiring intentional effort from companies and boards. Despite progress, there is still a considerable journey ahead to achieve true gender diversity, especially for women of color, in corporate leadership.

title: JFrog Announces Pricing of Its Initial Public Offering
summary: JFrog Ltd. announced the pricing of its initial public offering of 11,568,218 ordinary shares at $44.00 per share. Of these, 8,000,000 shares are offered by JFrog and 3,568,218 by existing shareholders. The shares were expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol "FROG" on September 16, 2020.

title: PNC Bank Appoints New Regional Leadership for Washington State and Portland
summary: PNC Bank announced new regional leadership appointments for its Washington State and Portland markets. Laura MacNeil will serve as regional president for Washington State, Jennifer Hare as head of Corporate Banking for Washington State, and JT Hutchinson as regional president and head of Corporate Banking for Portland. These appointments are part of PNC's strategic national expansion and aim to strengthen its presence and service delivery in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Weekly S&P 500 Chart Storm: All Eyes On Mega Cap Tech Stocks
summary: This article analyzes the S&P 500's recent pullback, highlighting the impact on mega-cap tech stocks and examining various market indicators. It delves into sentiment, seasonality, and the implications of the upcoming US presidential election on market trends, suggesting potential continued volatility. The author also discusses the shift towards intangible assets in corporate balance sheets and the declining equity risk premium.

title: Coca-Cola FEMSA recauda más de 700 millones de dólares con bono verde
summary: Coca-Cola FEMSA, the largest Coca-Cola bottler by sales volume, successfully issued its inaugural green bond in the international market, raising $705 million. This issuance, with a 12-year term and a coupon rate of 1.850%, is noted as the largest of its kind for a Latin American issuer and will fund green projects related to climate change, water care, and circular economy initiatives. Legal counsel for the transaction included Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton for the issuer and Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, alongside Galicia Abogados, for the underwriters BofA Securities, J.P. Morgan Securities, and Morgan Stanley.

title: Citigroup has just appointed the first female CEO of a Wall Street bank
summary: Jane Fraser has been appointed the next chief executive officer of Citigroup, making her the first woman to lead a major Wall Street bank. Her promotion is seen as a significant step towards greater gender diversity in the financial industry, where only a small percentage of top leadership roles are held by women. Fraser's career spans various critical roles within Citigroup and is credited with helping the bank recover after the financial crisis.

title: Lightspeed Announces Pricing of Initial Public Offering in The United States
summary: Lightspeed POS Inc. announced the pricing of its initial public offering in the United States and Canada, with underwriters agreeing to purchase 10 million subordinate voting shares from the Company and 1.65 million from Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec at US$30.50 per share. The shares are expected to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "LSPD" on September 11, 2020. The offering aims to strengthen Lightspeed's financial position and support its growth strategies.

title: Fidelity National Financial Prices $600 Million Of 2.450% Notes Due March 15, 2031
summary: Fidelity National Financial (FNF) has priced an issuance of $600 million of 2.450% senior notes due March 15, 2031. The notes were priced at 99.642% of their principal amount to yield 2.489% per annum, with interest paid semi-annually. The net proceeds will be used to repay outstanding indebtedness related to the FGL Holdings acquisition and for general corporate purposes.

title: Chase and Capital One to close local branches
summary: Two major bank branches, Chase and Capital One, are scheduled to close their locations on Chambers Street in the coming months. The Chase branch will close in the fourth quarter of 2020, while the Capital One branch will close on October 21, 2020. This decision contributes to a broader trend of bank branch closures in New York City, drawing mixed reactions from residents.

title: Vertafore to be Acquired by Roper Technologies
summary: Vertafore, an insurtech leader, announced its acquisition by Roper Technologies, Inc. (NYSE: ROP), a diversified technology company. The acquisition, expected to close in the third quarter subject to regulatory approval, will see Roper acquire Vertafore from Bain Capital Private Equity and Vista Equity Partners. Vertafore CEO Amy Zupon will continue to lead the company, which has significantly grown its employees and customer satisfaction since 2016.

title: Trump fires Tennessee Valley Authority chair, cites hiring of foreign workers
summary: President Donald Trump announced the firing of Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) chair, Skip Thompson, and another board member, citing the authority's practice of hiring foreign workers under H1-B visas. Trump also threatened to remove other board members and mandated that the new CEO's salary should not exceed $500,000, significantly less than the previous CEO's $8 million. The decision followed a TV ad criticizing the TVA for replacing American workers with foreign contractors, a move that Senator Lamar Alexander disputes, stating the TVA operates without taxpayer money and has competitive rates.

title: Citi, Bank of America join Morgan Stanley in carbon-disclosure group
summary: Bank of America and Citi have joined the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF), an organization aiming to standardize how banks measure and reduce their climate impact. Citi pledged $250 billion over the next five years for low-carbon solutions and aims to reduce CO2 emissions by 45% by 2025. These moves follow Morgan Stanley also joining PCAF, highlighting a growing trend among major U.S. banks to improve their green profiles and address climate change.

title: Strategic Education, Inc. to Acquire Laureate Education, Inc.’s Australia and New Zealand Academic Operations, Including Torrens University
summary: Strategic Education, Inc. announced its definitive agreement to acquire Laureate Education, Inc.'s Australia and New Zealand academic operations, including Torrens University, for $642.7 million in cash. This acquisition will expand Strategic Education's global presence, diversify its offerings, and is expected to be immediately accretive to its earnings. The transaction is anticipated to close by the first quarter of 2021, subject to regulatory approvals.

title: Regions to close 37 branches, including two in Tampa Bay
summary: Regions Bank is closing 37 branches, including two in Tampa Bay, as part of its network optimization strategy. This decision aligns with changing consumer preferences, which have been accelerated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The closures reflect a broader trend of banks adjusting their physical footprints in response to evolving customer banking habits.

title: A few of Charlotte’s largest companies just told employees they’ll work from home for the rest of 2020. Will others follow?
summary: Several major Charlotte-based companies, including Red Ventures, LendingTree, Ally, and Brighthouse Financial, have announced that employees will work remotely until at least early 2021 due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and related logistical challenges. This decision, influenced by school system changes and health concerns, raises questions about whether other large companies in the area will adopt similar long-term work-from-home policies, potentially reshaping the future of white-collar workplaces. Other large companies like Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Truist, and Duke Energy are still evaluating their return-to-office plans, largely maintaining remote work for most employees for the time being.

title: Morning Coffee: The hot new finance job that’s actually really old. Can you trust the interns with your computer network?
summary: The article discusses the resurgence of "direct lending" in finance, exemplified by Apollo Global Management's new business, noting its similarity to traditional banking functions that banks divested from due to regulatory changes. It also covers Morgan Stanley's in-office virtual internship in Shanghai due to new cybersecurity laws and touches on other finance-related news, including legal disputes, academic research, and green bond market activity.

title: Macy’s, Kohl’s suffer as brands, competitors and e-commerce step in to replace department stores
summary: Macy's and Kohl's have been downgraded to "sell" by UBS due to a shift in retail power towards brands and e-commerce. Department stores were already struggling before the pandemic, and their positions have further weakened, according to Bank of America. UBS also significantly reduced the price targets for Macy's and Kohl's.

title: More Wells Fargo customers say the bank decided to pause their mortgage payments without asking
summary: Numerous Wells Fargo customers across 14 states claim the bank unilaterally placed their mortgages into forbearance plans, affecting their credit reports and ability to refinance, without their consent. The bank attributes these incidents to misinterpretations of customer intentions, while critics like Sen. Sherrod Brown denounce the bank's "sloppy service and shoddy management." This practice has drawn comparisons to Wells Fargo's past scandals of enrolling customers in unwanted services.

title: Notre Dame elects three new Trustees
summary: The University of Notre Dame has elected three new members to its Board of Trustees: Justin R. Liu, Michael G. O’Grady, and Jennifer F. Scanlon. All three are Notre Dame alumni with significant leadership roles in their respective industries. Additionally, three former Trustees were elevated to Emeritus status, and two individuals were elected as Fellows of the University.

title: SEC charges former Morgan Stanley rep with stealing $6 million from clients
summary: The SEC has charged Michael Barry Carter, a former Morgan Stanley representative, with stealing approximately $6 million from brokerage customers and an elderly investment advisory client through unauthorized transfers between 2007 and 2019. Carter has pleaded guilty to parallel criminal charges and was fired by Morgan Stanley in 2019, with the firm stating that impacted clients have been reimbursed. He used the misappropriated funds to support a lavish lifestyle and concealed the fraud with false account statements.

title: nCino prices IPO above price range at $31 a share
summary: nCino Inc., a cloud-based software provider for financial institutions, priced its initial public offering at $31 a share, exceeding its proposed range due to strong investor demand. The company sold 8.06 million shares, raising $249.86 million, and plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes and working capital. Shares are expected to begin trading on Nasdaq under the ticker 'NCNO' with BofA and Barclays leading the underwriting.

title: PPP in CNY: Top 20 banks, lenders that doled out most loans to local businesses
summary: This article identifies the top 20 banks and lenders that distributed the most Paycheck Protection Program (PPP) loans to local businesses in Central New York. It highlights that independent community banks and credit unions performed the majority of lending, with M&T Bank leading. The article also provides a list of the top lenders and details about loan size distribution.

title: Rocky Mountain Institute launches the Center for Climate-Aligned Finance
summary: Rocky Mountain Institute (RMI) has launched the Center for Climate-Aligned Finance in collaboration with major financial institutions like Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, and JPMorgan Chase. The Center aims to facilitate the financial sector's role in guiding the global economy to net-zero emissions by mid-century by developing practical solutions and frameworks for carbon-intensive industries. It will work with financial institutions and corporations to accelerate the transition to a sustainable energy platform and foster climate alignment initiatives across various sectors.

title: Bank of America blows out its solar energy commitment with 10 deals in 3 states
summary: Bank of America has signed 10 agreements to purchase solar electricity for its operations in North Carolina, Texas, and South Carolina, totaling 200 megawatts (MWAC) of new solar capacity. These deals will supply over 340,000 megawatt-hours (MWh) of Green-e-certified renewable energy certificates annually, covering a significant portion of the bank's U.S. electricity use. A unique feature of many of these projects is the inclusion of pollinator habitats to support local biodiversity and agriculture in low-to-moderate-income communities.

title: White & Case Advises the Underwriters on Lemonade, Inc.'s Initial Public Offering
summary: White & Case LLP advised the underwriters on Lemonade, Inc.'s US$367 million initial public offering and listing on the New York Stock Exchange. Lemonade (NYSE: LMND) offers homeowners and renters insurance and has expanded globally, with the offering including the full exercise of the underwriters' option to purchase additional shares. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, and Allen & Company LLC acted as managing bookrunners for the offering.

title: Valley National Bank views today's business environment as a glass half full
summary: Valley National Bank's Tampa-based commercial real estate lending team is cautiously optimistic about the region's economic rebound despite the COVID-19 pandemic. They are implementing stricter lending practices, including requiring more equity and increased due diligence, but have also processed over $2.3 billion in PPP loans. The bank is buoyed by falling unemployment claims, rising consumer confidence, and anticipates growth in certain commercial real estate sectors.

title: Credicorp emite bonos por 500 millones de dólares en el mercado internacional
summary: Credicorp, a Peruvian financial services holding company, issued $500 million in bonds in international markets with a coupon rate of 2.750% and maturity in 2025. The proceeds from this operation will be used to finance corporate purposes. Various law firms advised Credicorp and the initial purchasers, Bank of America Securities, J.P. Morgan Securities, and Goldman Sachs.

title: Lululemon acquisition Mirror could generate $700 million and reach 600,000 subscribers by 2023: Bank of America
summary: Bank of America analysts project that Lululemon Athletica's newly acquired at-home fitness company, Mirror, could generate $700 million in revenue and attract 600,000 subscribers by 2023. This projection is based on the increased interest in digital fitness, partly due to the coronavirus pandemic. If achieved, Mirror's revenue would account for approximately 10% of Lululemon's total annual revenue.

title: Waterstone Mortgage Head Andy Peach To Resign
summary: Andy Peach, President and CEO of Waterstone Mortgage Corporation, has announced his resignation. Peach, who was appointed last August, is leaving the role with over 30 years of industry experience. A replacement has not yet been named.

title: First look: JPMorgan Chase's downtown branch to open next week
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. is opening its newest Nashville branch next week at the base of the ServiceSource Tower in downtown Nashville. This will be the bank's flagship Nashville location, situated near Broadway and several competitors like Regions Bank, Fifth Third Bank, and SunTrust Bank.

title: Netflix will move $100 million into Black-owned banks
summary: Netflix Inc. is pledging $100 million to Black-owned banks and financial institutions to support African-American communities. This initiative involves an initial $25 million investment in the Black Economic Development Initiative and $10 million to Hope Credit Union, with an ongoing commitment to steer 2% of its cash to these organizations. This move follows calls for corporate support for racial equality and aims to address systemic inequality by boosting historically underfunded institutions.

title: CoreLogic Weighs Unsolicited Bid from Cannae Holdings, Senator Investment Group
summary: Cannae Holdings Inc. and Senator Investment Group LP have proposed acquiring CoreLogic Inc. for $5.16 billion, or $65 a share in cash, representing a 37% premium over CoreLogic's stock price on June 15. CoreLogic stated it would review the unsolicited bid, with the bidders criticizing CoreLogic's current strategy and recent guidance change as a defensive move. The firms are calling for CoreLogic to hire advisers and form a special committee to negotiate the transaction.

title: Japan's SoftBank unloads a $21 billion stake in T-Mobile US as the great sell-off commences
summary: SoftBank Group Corp. is selling a $21 billion stake in T-Mobile US Inc. as part of a larger $42 billion asset sale to finance stock buybacks and reduce debt, motivated by record losses in its Vision Fund. This move comes after significant write-downs in investments like WeWork and Uber. The complex transaction involves T-Mobile holding a public offering and transferring nearly 200 million shares owned by SoftBank.

title: PFPC Selected by Franklin Templeton Investments to Service New Jersey 529 Plans
summary: PFPC Inc., a member of The PNC Financial Services Group, Inc., has been selected by Franklin Templeton Investments to provide investor servicing for both the Franklin Templeton 529 College Savings Plan and the NJBEST 529 College Savings Plan. This multi-year contract involves PFPC providing recordkeeping, reporting, and investor servicing for these plans, expanding its role in the growing 529 college savings plan market. The collaboration will leverage PFPC's Global Enterprise Platform to support expanded distribution goals and complex servicing needs for these college savings programs.

title: Banking by appointment could stick as a post-COVID-19 customer habit
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led financial institutions to implement appointment-based banking to manage social distancing, a practice that some bankers believe will continue post-pandemic. This system helps banks manage staff levels, triage customers, and offer convenience for customers working from home. It also complements digital banking options for those who still prefer a personal touch, with banks like Regions seeing a significant increase in appointment volume.

title: The 20-Year Bond Is Changing The Shape Of The Yield Curve
summary: The U.S. Treasury's re-issuance of 20-year bonds in May 2020, for the first time since 1986, is significantly altering the shape of the yield curve. This new issuance has created a "kink" in the curve, with front-end rates indicating lower interest rates while longer-dated rates have moved higher. As liquidity in this sector builds, experts anticipate that the kink will moderate, influencing futures trading and overall market liquidity.

title: Could a Western Union–MoneyGram deal help two giants fend off fintech disrupters?
summary: Western Union is reportedly considering an acquisition of rival MoneyGram, a move that could help both remittance giants better compete against fintech disruptors. MoneyGram has struggled financially since a failed acquisition attempt in 2018, making it a potentially attractive target for Western Union to expand its global retail network and digital capabilities. However, such a deal faces challenges including MoneyGram's debt, potential antitrust issues, and Western Union's mixed history with large acquisitions.

title: Morgan Stanley's Gorman 'thrilled' with ETrade purchase
summary: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman expresses immense satisfaction with the acquisition of ETrade, highlighting the online trading firm's technology, digital banking capabilities, and management team. He plans to retain the ETrade brand, possibly as "ETrade powered by Morgan Stanley," recognizing its value to clients. Gorman believes the deal expands Morgan Stanley's online platform, diversifies the company, and strengthens its digital offerings, particularly appealing to a younger demographic.

title: Bank of America, U.S. Bank, PNC and others pledge millions toward racial equality
summary: Several major financial institutions, including Bank of America, U.S. Bank, and PNC, have pledged millions to racial equality initiatives. These commitments involve boosting loans to Black-owned businesses, funding community grants, and investing in organizations that address economic inequality, with some pledges specifically addressing anti-Asian hatred. The efforts are a response to the ongoing focus on racial justice and the disproportionate impact of systemic issues on communities of color.

title: U.S. Bancorp pledges $116 million to address racial inequality
summary: U.S. Bancorp announced a $116 million pledge to combat racial and economic inequality following the death of George Floyd. The initiative includes significant capital for African American-owned businesses, a new fund for grants addressing systemic inequities, and a community development financial institutions partnership program. The bank also plans to increase partnerships with African American suppliers, promote people of color to leadership, and rebuild damaged branches in Minneapolis

title: No quiet retirement for longtime Webster Financial chief
summary: James Smith, former CEO of Webster Financial, is actively involved in developing an economic action plan for Connecticut, even in retirement, demonstrating a continued commitment to public service. His work, initially derailed by COVID-19, now focuses on reopening, recovery, and reimagining the state's economy, with a particular concern for small businesses and urban centers. Smith advocates for retired bankers to invest their career knowledge back into their communities, emphasizing the noble nature of banking and civic responsibility.

title: Charles Schwab lands DOJ approval to buy TD Ameritrade
summary: The U.S. Justice Department's antitrust division has approved Charles Schwab's proposed $26 billion acquisition of TD Ameritrade, clearing the way for the merger. This combination is expected to solidify Schwab's dominant position in the discount-brokerage market and help both firms manage costs in a zero-commission trading environment. The deal is anticipated to close in the latter half of the year, with integration taking 18 to 36 months.

title: Capital One Announces Capital One, National Association and Capital One Bank (USA), National Association Any and All Cash Tender Offers for $7.55 Billion of Notes
summary: Capital One announced cash tender offers for approximately $7.55 billion of notes issued by its subsidiaries, Capital One, National Association, and Capital One Bank (USA), National Association. The offers allow holders to sell certain securities back to Capital One for cash, with varying purchase prices depending on the note series. The tender offers are set to expire on June 5, 2020, with a settlement date expected on June 10, 2020.

title: Embrace Disruption to Tenth Degree With This ETF
summary: The article highlights the ALPS Disruptive Technologies ETF (DTEC) as a solution for investors to gain broad exposure to 10 themes reshaping the technological landscape, including Healthcare Innovation, Cloud Computing, and FinTech. It emphasizes the significant growth potential of themes like cloud computing and fintech, as well as the importance of 3D printing in industries like defense and healthcare. The ETF offers a way to embrace the transformative power of disruptive technologies.

title: Chinese Gaming Firm NetEase to Launch $2.5 Billion Hong Kong Stock Sale
summary: Chinese game developer NetEase Inc. is preparing to launch a $2.5 billion stock offering in Hong Kong, following a trend of U.S.-listed Chinese companies seeking secondary listings in the city amid rising U.S.-China tensions. This move, along with JD.com Inc.'s planned $3 billion offering, highlights a shift towards Hong Kong as a listing destination, especially after a proposed U.S. bill could force Chinese companies to delist from American markets. NetEase plans to use the proceeds for expansion into music streaming and online education, with its Hong Kong debut expected on June 11.

title: Christine Y. Zhao Celebrated for Dedication to the Field of Finance
summary: Christine Y. Zhao has been recognized by Marquis Who's Who for her extensive and accomplished career in finance, spanning more than two decades. She currently serves as a Board Director for Nasdaq-listed BeyondSpring Inc. and a Venture Partner at YuanMing Capital, having previously held significant roles at JPMorgan, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and as CFO for private equity-backed companies including Best Inc. Her career highlights include driving strategy, business execution, and successful financial initiatives across various global institutions and industries, in addition to her significant community involvement.

title: Occidental is sued by shareholders, bondholders over Anadarko merger
summary: Occidental Petroleum is facing a lawsuit from shareholders and bondholders who claim they incurred billions in losses due to the company's alleged concealment of its financial vulnerability after acquiring Anadarko Petroleum for $35.7 billion. Investors argue that Occidental failed to disclose in its registration statements how quadrupling its debt would expose it to falling oil prices and undermine its ability to maintain its dividend and boost shale oil production. The lawsuit also names Occidental's CEO, former CFO, several directors, and banks that underwrote its bonds, alleging inadequate due diligence.

title: Is Len Blavatnik about to complete the shrewdest deal in the history of the record business?
summary: The article discusses how Len Blavatnik's Access Industries is poised to entirely recover its $3.3 billion investment in Warner Music Group through dividends and the upcoming Nasdaq IPO, while still maintaining majority ownership. It highlights the potential for this to be one of the shrewdest deals in music business history, valuing WMG at approximately $16 billion post-IPO. Blavatnik is also set to retain significant voting power, effectively calling the shots.

title: Herbalife sells $600 million of junk bonds so it can buy back shares
summary: Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. sold $600 million in junk bonds to fund share buybacks, an unusual move during the pandemic when most companies sought liquidity. The company's business has performed well, with net sales increasing, despite ongoing scrutiny of its multilevel marketing structure. Ratings agencies Moody's and S&P assigned non-investment grade ratings to the bonds, highlighting the company's business model fragility and regulatory investigations.

title: Galicia-Ualá: se consolida la colaboración entre la industria bancaria y las fintech
summary: The fintech Ualá has reached 2 million cards issued and is developing alliances with several financial entities, including Banco Galicia. Founder and CEO Pierpaolo Barbieri highlighted the collaborative model between banks and fintechs, emphasizing that Ualá's services are more affordable and aim for financial inclusion, especially outside major cities. The company has seen significant growth during the COVID-19 quarantine and plans to more than double its workforce by year-end.

title: Hershey Company pledges to end deforestation as part of its supply chain
summary: The Hershey Company has committed to ending deforestation in its global cocoa supply chain by stopping new deforestation and promoting agroforestry. This initiative involves not sourcing cocoa from areas with recent deforestation and implementing tree planting programs.
