Key topics included anticipating an economic downturn, the impact of federal regulations, challenges and opportunities presented by technology and cybersecurity, and struggles to attract new talent to the banking sector in Nevada.

title: GEO Group Running Out of Banks as 100% of Known Banking Partners Say ‘No’ to the Private Prison Sector
summary: All publicly known banking partners of GEO Group have committed to ending ties with the private prison and immigrant detention industry, representing an estimated 87.4% shortfall in credit and term loans. This move follows demands from activists and investors, significantly impacting industry giants GEO Group and CoreCivic, whose stock prices are near historic lows. The article also discusses five banks that have not yet made the commitment to stop extending credit lines to CoreCivic and the broader implications for the private prison sector.

title: Banco Santander compensará a 36 mil consumidores afectados por cobros en líneas de sobregiro
summary: Banco Santander will compensate 36,041 consumers totaling 886 million pesos for unjustified charges on overdraft lines between 2009 and 2016. This action stems from efforts by SERNAC, Chile's consumer protection agency, to address improper charges by several banks, including Banco de Chile, BBVA, and Security. The compensation varies, with some consumers receiving a uniform amount and others a partial refund of the commissions charged.

title: RBC, Santander, Mizuho Said to Win Coveted Roles on Aramco IPO
summary: Royal Bank of Canada, Banco Santander SA, and Mizuho Financial Group Inc. are among the banks selected as bookrunners for Saudi Aramco's initial public offering. Other financial institutions, including BOC International, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Saudi Fransi Capital, Al Rajhi Capital, Riyad Bank, and EFG Hermes, have also secured roles in the highly anticipated IPO. This development indicates Saudi Aramco is proceeding with its plans to list as early as November.

title: Bank of America CEO Says His Company Has to Make Profit and ‘Take a Stand’
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan stated that the company has a responsibility to do more than just generate profits, emphasizing the need to address contentious issues like gun control. He highlighted the impact of such issues on employees, explaining why the bank must take a stand.

title: Payroll processor exec charged in $70M bank fraud
summary: Michael Mann, owner of MyPayrollHR, was charged with fraudulently obtaining about $70 million in a bank fraud scheme involving "kiting" funds between accounts at Pioneer Bancorp and Bank of America. This scheme caused temporary payment disruptions for roughly 8,000 employees at nearly 400 companies. Mann admitted the fraud was in response to business and financial pressures, claiming he used the funds to sustain existing businesses and start new ones.

title: Exclusive —J.P. Morgan Private Bank comes to Pittsburgh
summary: J.P. Morgan Private Bank is set to open a new office in Pittsburgh in early October, expanding its physical presence in a region it has served clients in for over two decades. This move comes as JPMorgan Chase & Co. continues its broader expansion in the Pittsburgh market, with a managing director hired from BNY Mellon Wealth Management to lead the new private banking unit. The expansion highlights increasing competition among banking institutions in the area.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires $1 Billion-Asset Texas Team from UBS
summary: Morgan Stanley has hired a high-producing team, Jeff Parker and Rafael Herrera, from UBS Wealth Management in Houston, managing $1 billion in assets and generating $4 million in annual production. The firm also added advisor Sari Warsaw from UBS in Long Island. These hires highlight Morgan Stanley's selective exceptions to its broader hiring constraints, contrasting with the general industry trend of wirehouses cutting recruiting budgets.

title: Microsoft customers gain a financial services advocate in new CVP Bill Borden
summary: Microsoft has appointed Bill Borden as Corporate Vice President of Financial Services, leveraging his 20 years of industry experience from Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citigroup. Borden will lead Microsoft's go-to-market strategy in financial services, focusing on digital transformation and empowering intelligent banking solutions. His appointment underscores Microsoft's investment in industry-specific expertise to better serve its customers.

title: KeyCorp CEO Beth Mooney will retire in May 2020, to be succeeded by Chris Gorman
summary: KeyCorp CEO Beth Mooney will retire in May 2020 and will be succeeded by Chris Gorman. Gorman, currently president of banking, will take over as chairman and CEO after serving as president and chief operating officer until Mooney's retirement. The transition is part of the board's succession management process, ensuring a seamless leadership change.

title: Wells Fargo hires former BofA exec for leadership role in technology
summary: Wells Fargo & Co. has appointed Tracy Kerrins, a former Bank of America executive, as the chief information officer of its Enterprise Functions Technology team. Kerrins will be based in Charlotte, North Carolina. This move signals Wells Fargo's continued focus on strengthening its technology leadership.

title: Which banks are biggest in Charlotte?
summary: Bank of America Corp. significantly leads Charlotte's banking market share, controlling over 79% in Mecklenburg County with more than $149.5 billion in local deposits as of June 30. Despite a slight decrease from the previous year, BofA also holds 73% of the Charlotte-Concord-Gastonia metro area market share. Wells Fargo & Co. ranks second with 14.4% of the market share.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires Merrill Pair from Private Wealth Mega-Team
summary: Morgan Stanley hired Joseph Castagnola, a private wealth managing director from Merrill Lynch's Jones Zafari group which managed $16.5 billion in customer assets, along with an associate, Nicholas J. Moore. This move highlights Morgan Stanley's willingness to make exceptions to its "Spartan recruiting regimen" for high-producing advisors, despite having left the Protocol for Broker Recruiting. Concurrently, Merrill Lynch continues to see outflows, with another team joining RBC Wealth Management and several other teams also departing for RBC at the end of August.

title: Finance start-up SoFi strikes deal to put its name on new LA stadium for the Rams and Chargers
summary: Financial technology start-up SoFi has secured a 20-year naming rights deal for the new Los Angeles football stadium, which will be home to both the Rams and the Chargers. The "SoFi Stadium" deal is reportedly worth $400 million and aims to increase brand awareness for the eight-year-old venture capital-backed company. This move makes SoFi the first Silicon Valley start-up to have its name on a major NFL sports arena, strategically expanding its reach beyond its financial services offerings.

title: Time for a Trade on Financials, But Which Way?
summary: This article discusses the financial sector's performance in August 2019, a period of heightened volatility due to trade tensions and inverted treasury yields. Despite recession fears and an interest rate cut, major banks reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings, indicating underlying health in lending and liquidity. The piece suggests that while market anxiety persists, the fundamental strength of financials offers potential for both bullish and bearish trades using Direxion's leveraged ETFs.

title: 10x Genomics CEO Calls IPO a Validation of the Company’s Years-Long Strategy
summary: Shares of 10x Genomics surged over 35% on its Nasdaq debut, validating the company's long-term strategy in gene sequencing and genomic analysis. CEO Serge Saxonov views the successful IPO as a testament to their execution and scale, positioning the company to continue advancing human health. The company plans to use the funds to expand its research and maintain its leadership in the rapidly growing genomics market.

title: Sebi imposes Rs 12 lakh fine on ICICI Bank, compliance officer for disclosure lapses
summary: SEBI has imposed a total fine of Rs 12 lakh on ICICI Bank Ltd and its compliance officer, Sandeep Batra, for disclosure lapses. The fine was levied due to the delayed disclosure of a binding agreement signed with Bank of Rajasthan for its amalgamation, which was deemed price-sensitive information. ICICI Bank was fined Rs 10 lakh, and Sandeep Batra was fined Rs 2 lakh for failing to ensure timely disclosure.

title: The Yield Curve Inversion May Be Different This Time
summary: The article discusses the recent inversion of the treasury yield curve and argues that this instance might be different from historical inversions. It suggests that short-term factors, such as global recession fears driving investors to safe assets and the Federal Reserve's reluctance to aggressively cut interest rates, are primarily responsible for the current inversion, rather than a fundamental economic outlook. The author posits that aggressive rate cuts by the Fed could eliminate the inversion and spur investment.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires Internet Banker Mehta From Bank of America
summary: Morgan Stanley has hired Umi Mehta, an investment banker specializing in internet companies, from Bank of America Corp. Mehta will serve as a managing director of global internet at Morgan Stanley's Menlo Park office, co-leading the group with Kate Claassen. This move strengthens Morgan Stanley's internet investment banking team in Silicon Valley.

title: Citigroup doubles down on credit cards even as U.S. economy softens
summary: Citigroup is heavily investing in its credit card business, particularly through zero-interest balance transfers, despite concerns about a softening U.S. economy. While this strategy carries risks from higher-risk borrowers, Citigroup asserts that tough underwriting standards and low delinquency rates will protect the bank. The credit card unit has become a crucial driver of revenue and profit growth for the bank following the 2007-2009 financial crisis.

title: Why Cathy Bessant sees technology making a bigger impact at Bank of America
summary: Cathy Bessant, chief operations and technology officer at Charlotte-based Bank of America, believes technology will have a greater impact on the company. She oversees 95,000 employees and contractors globally and is set to share her expertise as a keynote speaker at the Charlotte CIO of the Year ORBIE Awards.

title: Howes: Amid auto talks, Ford lays claim to being 'America's auto company'
summary: Amid upcoming UAW contract talks, Ford Motor Co. is strategically emphasizing its position as "America's auto company," contrasting with competitors like GM which build more vehicles abroad. Executive Chairman Bill Ford highlighted that Ford builds more vehicles and employs more hourly workers in the U.S. than any other automaker. This positioning is seen as an asset in negotiations and a defense against potential political criticism, as Ford leads in U.S. production and exports while minimizing non-NAFTA imports compared to GM and FCA.

title: PHOTOS: Why Bank of America expanded into Lancaster County with first branch
summary: Bank of America has opened its first branch in Lancaster County, located in the Carolina Lakes area off U.S. Highway 521 in Indian Land. The 3,800-square-foot branch, which had a soft opening on August 19, features a modern design. This expansion signifies Bank of America's investment in the region.

title: After a Decade And a Merger, the BofA-First Data JV Closes Out
summary: The long-running merchant-acquiring joint venture between Bank of America and First Data, called Bank of America Merchant Services, is ending. Bank of America will pursue an independent merchant-acquiring strategy starting next June, while Fiserv/First Data will retain 51% of the merchant portfolio and BofA will keep 49%. The dissolution reflects each company's strategic direction and is not indicative of their relationship, as First Data will continue as an important service provider.

title: BofA chases $10 trillion private capital pool driving M&A
summary: Bank of America is strategically focusing on the burgeoning $10 trillion private capital market, targeting sovereign wealth funds and buyout firms. This initiative aims to capitalize on the increasing surge in dealmaking activities within this sector. The bank is building specialized teams to support this growth.

title: New Highwoods Properties CEO's base salary rises 36%
summary: Raleigh-based REIT Highwoods Properties announced its reentry into the Charlotte market with the upcoming purchase of Bank of America Tower in uptown. This news is accompanied by information regarding the new Highwoods Properties CEO's base salary increasing by 36%.

title: Bank of Montreal (BMO) pulling back on reinsurance, citing climate change
summary: The Bank of Montreal (BMO) is scaling back its reinsurance operations, specifically its property and casualty reinsurance underwriting arm BMO Reinsurance Limited, due to inadequate returns and the increasing impact of climate change. CEO Darryl White and CFO Tom Flynn cited higher volatility and below-expectation returns, exacerbated by heavy catastrophe losses in recent years and concerns about more frequent and severe weather-related claims. BMO views this business as no longer meeting its risk-return expectations and not core to its strategy.

title: Bank of America Names Tony Bland As Merrill Market Exec For D.C.
summary: Bank of America has appointed Tony Bland as its Managing Director and Market Executive for Merrill Lynch Wealth Management in Washington, D.C. Bland will lead Merrill Lynch's financial advisors, corporate benefits specialists, and private wealth advisors in the Greater Washington market. He previously held a similar role in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, where he was instrumental in integrating various Bank of America business lines.

title: Bank of America’s CEO has one simple reason why he doesn’t see a recession looming
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan believes a recession is not imminent because the U.S. consumer remains healthy and continues to spend. His comments come amidst investor concerns about the U.S. economy due to ongoing trade tensions between the Trump administration and China. Moynihan's assessment highlights consumer spending as a key factor in maintaining economic stability.

title: Dow Corning’s 24-Year Bankruptcy Nears End on $172 Million Deal
summary: Dow Corning's 24-year bankruptcy case is nearing its conclusion following a $172 million settlement with a group of banks over disputed interest payments. The silicone breast implant maker, now operating as Dow Silicones Corp. and a subsidiary of Dow Inc., filed for Chapter 11 in 1995. This agreement resolves a significant outstanding matter in the long-running case.

title: ICE hires BVAL’s Pierce Lord as a director of fixed income analytics
summary: Intercontinental Exchange Inc. (ICE) has hired Pierce Lord from Bloomberg LP’s BVAL as director of fixed income analytics to expand ICE's analytics offering, particularly in evaluating fixed income markets. Lord previously served as global head of corporate, government and municipal valuation at Bloomberg’s BVAL. This move signals ICE's continued expansion in providing evaluations and analytics for fixed income markets, following recent product launches like a new municipal index and yield curve.

title: How Bank of America logged latest win in lawsuit over virtual assistant Erica
summary: Bank of America Corp. achieved a victory in a trademark dispute concerning its virtual financial assistant, Erica. While this marks a win for the Charlotte-based bank, the legal battle is not yet concluded. This article details the latest development in the ongoing lawsuit.

title: Makeover at Wells Fargo Advisors well-received
summary: Wells Fargo Advisors is undergoing a reorganization of its wealth management business, reducing its corporate structure and cutting about a dozen market manager positions. This move is seen by some as a necessary step to cut waste and duplicative management, leading to 91 markets within the firm. The firm is also consolidating its bank brokerage channel into the wirehouse channel as part of a $4 billion cost-cutting plan.

title: US 30-year bond yield falls below 2% for first time
summary: The US 30-year bond yield fell below 2% for the first time ever, driven by investors seeking safety amidst growing fears over the global economy and renewed trade tensions. This rally in government bonds, alongside weak data from Germany and China, indicates rising recession risks and has led to an inversion of the yield curve, historically a harbinger of economic downturn. The stock of global negative-yielding debt also surged past $16 trillion, reflecting the high price money managers are willing to pay for secure sovereign bonds.

title: Warren Buffett Is a Huge Backer of U.S. Banks
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway holds nearly $100 billion in financial-services stocks, demonstrating his significant commitment to the U.S. economy. These holdings, which include banks, payment companies, insurers, and a ratings firm, now constitute about one-fifth of Berkshire's total market capitalization. This represents a substantial increase from 2010, when financial-sector investments made up 12% of the company's market cap.

title: Main yield curve inverts as 2-year yield tops 10-year rate, triggering recession warning
summary: The main U.S. yield curve inverted as the 2-year Treasury yield surpassed the 10-year rate, a phenomenon historically preceding economic recessions. This inversion, along with the 30-year bond yield hitting an all-time low, signals increasing investor concern about a slowdown in global economies. While the inversion is a reliable indicator, a recession typically follows 22 months later, and the S&P 500 often sees gains in the year following such an event.

title: Brighton chairman Tony Bloom wants Albion to be top 10 Premier League club
summary: Brighton chairman Tony Bloom aims for the club to become a top 10 Premier League team after securing a 12-year, £100m sponsorship deal with American Express. This deal bolsters their financial standing significantly, moving them into the top tier for club sponsorships in the league. Despite finishing 17th last season, the club is investing in infrastructure and personnel to achieve this ambitious goal, highlighting their growth over the past decade.

title: Broadcom to Buy Symantec Enterprise Division
summary: Broadcom has agreed to acquire Symantec's enterprise division for $10.7 billion in cash, marking its second major software acquisition after CA Technologies. This deal will refocus Symantec on its consumer products and aims to generate $2 billion in sustainable revenue for Broadcom, along with $1.3 billion in EBITDA. Symantec plans to return $8.2 billion after taxes to shareholders via a special dividend of $12 a share.

title: Refinery could be sued over toxic waste
summary: Environmental groups are moving to sue Phillips 66 over allegations of years of mismanaging hazardous waste at its Wilmington and Carson facilities, which they claim puts South Bay residents at risk. This legal action follows concerns first raised by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency four years ago and frustration with what advocates describe as lax oversight by federal and state regulators. The environmentalists are particularly concerned about a leak of toxic selenium waste and the EPA's recent decrease in enforcement actions.

title: Looking for Trade War Protection? Look to Corporate Bond ETFs
summary: As equities face vulnerability due to the US/China trade war, investors can find protection and income through corporate bonds and related ETFs. The FlexShares Credit‐Scored US Corporate Bond Index Fund (SKOR) is highlighted, focusing on high-quality corporate issues and excluding illiquid ones for better transparency. Analysts recommend investment-grade corporate bonds for resilience during trade disruptions, with SKOR holding over 91% of its assets in A or BBB-rated bonds.

title: Why Halliburton broadened paid family leave
summary: Halliburton expanded its paid family leave policy to offer eight weeks of fully paid bonding leave for new parents, or a two-week payout option. This move was a strategic decision to enhance employee benefits within the oil and gas industry and address increasing employee demand for family-friendly policies. Despite initial concerns from operations leaders, the company implemented provisions and communication strategies to ensure the program's success as a cultural shift.

title: Apple, Goldman Sachs start issuing Apple Cards to consumers
summary: Apple and Goldman Sachs have begun issuing Apple Cards to a limited number of consumers. This virtual credit card, designed to work with the iPhone, offers 2% cashback, no fees, and strong privacy features, aiming to diversify Apple's revenue and expand Goldman Sachs' consumer banking brand. Analysts predict it will strengthen Apple's ecosystem loyalty, with potential high-margin revenue growth by 2023.

title: Is It A Bad Time To Buy The iShares China Large-Cap ETF (IZZ)?
summary: This article discusses whether it's a good time to invest in the iShares China Large-Cap ETF (ASX: IZZ) given the US-China trade war. It provides details on IZZ, including its asset allocation, performance, and fees, comparing it to other ETFs like IVV. The author advises caution due to trade war uncertainties but highlights China's growth potential as a future investment opportunity.

title: LendingTree embroiled in legal dispute with a subsidiary over $40 million dividend
summary: LendingTree is entangled in a legal dispute with its bankrupt subsidiary, Home Loan Center Inc., over a $40 million dividend authorized by LendingTree CEO Doug Lebda. Home Loan Center claims the transfer was fraudulent as it was dissolving and had outstanding debts, leading to allegations of Lebda breaching his fiduciary duty. LendingTree disputes the claims but has begun settlement talks, while stating it will vigorously contest the allegations if no settlement is reached.

title: Spanish banking giant charged with corruption
summary: Spain's National Court has charged Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA) with "corruption and breach of confidence" for allegedly contracting disgraced former police chief Jose Manuel Villarejo to illegally tap phones in 2004. The suspicions relate to BBVA's efforts to prevent a takeover bid by construction company Sacyr, and nine current or former managers are under investigation. BBVA denies wrongdoing, despite admitting to using Villarejo's firm Cenyt, and its former executive chairman, Francisco Gonzalez, resigned due to the probe.

title: BB&T, SunTrust Promise Bonuses to 40,000 Employees After Merger Closes
summary: Following the approval of their $29.7 billion merger, BB&T Corp. and SunTrust Banks Inc. announced that 40,000 employees would receive $1,500 bonuses when the deal closes. This merger, creating Truist Financial Corp., will be the largest banking deal since 2009 and is expected to finalize in late September or early October. Additionally, SunTrust brokers received retention-bonus loans, and SunTrust CEO William H. Rogers Jr.'s compensation package was approved.

title: Bank of America, First Data End Payments Partnership
summary: Bank of America is ending its decadeslong payment-processing joint venture with First Data, a move that will give the bank more control over its merchant payment business. The partnership is set to expire in June 2020. Bank of America expects to record an impairment charge between $1.7 billion and $2.1 billion in the third quarter due to this termination.

title: Bank of America ends joint venture with Fiserv's First Data
summary: Bank of America announced on Monday that it will terminate its electronic payment services joint venture with First Data Corp next June, following Fiserv Inc.'s acquisition of First Data. This termination is expected to result in a non-cash, pretax impairment charge of $1.7 billion to $2.1 billion for Bank of America in the third quarter of 2019. Despite the end of the partnership, both parties have agreed to continue providing uninterrupted services to Banc of America Merchant Services clients until at least June 2023.

title: Buffett buys more Bank of America stock, with stake’s value rising to $29 billion
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has significantly increased its stake in Bank of America, making it the largest shareholder. The value of Berkshire's holdings in the money-center bank now exceeds $29 billion. This move was disclosed in a Form 3 filing with the SEC, indicating Berkshire Hathaway owns 950 million shares, or over 10% of Bank of America's outstanding common shares.

title: Alex and Ani Sues Bank of America for Discrimination
summary: Jewelry company Alex and Ani has filed a lawsuit against Bank of America, alleging discriminatory lending practices against its women-led company and seeking $1.1 billion in damages. The lawsuit claims Bank of America breached their credit agreement by fraudulently declaring a default and that the bank's actions are driven by a gender bias, particularly after a female CFO, Andrea Ruda, took over. Bank of America denies the allegations, stating the company has faced serious financial challenges for two years and that the loan is spread across seven banks.

title: Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings, Inc. Announces Pricing of its Offering of Common Stock
summary: Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings, Inc. announced the pricing of its public offering of 100 million shares of common stock at $3.50 per share. The company also granted underwriters a 30-day option for an additional 15 million shares. Proceeds from the offering will be used to redeem a significant portion of its 9.25% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2024.

title: Banca Transilvania S.A.
summary: Banca Transilvania partnered with IBM Business Partner IT Smart Systems to implement an open banking platform using IBM software, enabling them to comply with the PSD2 directive. This platform provides a flexible, secure environment for integrating fintech services and enhancing customer experience, while also allowing the bank to adapt to future market demands. The solution helped Banca Transilvania meet regulatory deadlines, reduce development costs, and ensure strong security for its open banking initiatives.

title: What Bank of America’s New Patent Means for Ripple (XRP)
summary: Bank of America has filed a new patent that appears to utilize Ripple's distributed ledger system for real-time net settlements. This patent, if implemented, would mark the first time Bank of America works with another cryptocurrency project for adoption, potentially serving as a significant endorsement for Ripple's technology in foreign currency trading. The proposed system aims to streamline cross-border payments and eliminate the need for accounts in partner institutions, with Bank of America acting as a validator node.

title: Bank of America to open branches in Cincinnati, Columbus
summary: Bank of America announced plans to open 30 branches in Ohio over the next two years, including 15 in Cincinnati, marking its first retail presence in the state. The expansion is part of a broader strategy to open 350 new branches across various U.S. markets and builds upon the bank's existing commercial, business banking, and wealth management services in Ohio. The move aims to better serve clients and demonstrates a commitment to responsible growth in the region.

title: Chinese game-streaming platform DouYu prices U.S. IPO
summary: Chinese game-streaming platform DouYu International successfully priced its Nasdaq IPO, raising $775 million by selling 67.4 million American depositary shares at $11.50 each. This makes it the largest Chinese IPO in the U.S. for 2019. The company, which specializes in streaming eSports and other gaming events, started trading under the ticker symbol DOYU with a $3.73 billion valuation by market close on its first day.

title: Here's why Bank of America's CEO likes his execs on other companies' boards
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan encourages his executives to serve on the boards of other companies. He views this experience as valuable for developing future leaders, including his own potential successor. Moynihan believes diverse board experience is crucial for those aspiring to CEO roles.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock saw gains on Wednesday despite the bank lowering its full-year outlook for net interest income. This adjustment was made in anticipation of interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank also reported mixed second-quarter results with profit beating expectations but net interest income and sales and trading revenue falling short.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock rebounded despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook, anticipating interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank reported a Q2 profit that exceeded expectations, although net interest income was slightly below forecasts. Sales and trading revenue declined significantly, particularly in fixed income, currencies, commodities, and equities.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock saw a gain despite lowering its full-year outlook for net interest income due to anticipated interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank reported a Q2 profit that beat expectations, although net interest income was slightly below forecasts. Sales and trading revenue declined significantly, marking a fourth consecutive quarterly drop for fixed income, currencies, and commodities, and a substantial decrease in equities revenue.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock saw a gain after its post-earnings conference call, even though the bank cut its full-year net interest income outlook due to anticipated interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank reported a beat on second-quarter profit but slightly missed on net interest income, with significant declines in sales and trading revenue, particularly in fixed income, currencies, commodities, and equities.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock gained Wednesday despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook, anticipating interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank reported an upbeat second-quarter profit but slightly missed on net interest income, with sales and trading revenue declining, particularly in fixed income, currencies, commodities, and equities.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock saw a gain after its post-earnings conference call, despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook. This adjustment was made in anticipation of two Federal Reserve interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank also reported mixed second-quarter results, with profit beating expectations but net interest income falling short, and sales and trading revenue declining significantly.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Shares of Bank of America Corp. saw a modest gain despite the bank lowering its full-year outlook for net interest income. This adjustment was made as the bank anticipates interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. While the bank's second-quarter profit surpassed expectations, net interest income was slightly below forecasts, and sales and trading revenue experienced a decline.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock gained Wednesday despite the bank lowering its full-year outlook for net interest income due to anticipated interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank reported better-than-expected second-quarter profits, though net interest income was slightly lower and sales and trading revenue declined significantly. This comes as the bank expects growth even with the challenges.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock saw a gain despite the bank lowering its full-year outlook for net interest income. This adjustment was made in anticipation of interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank also reported mixed second-quarter results, with profit beating expectations but net interest income falling short, and sales and trading revenue declining significantly.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock sawed toward a gain despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook due to anticipated interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The company reported better-than-expected second-quarter profit but slightly lower net interest income, with sales and trading revenue also falling. This performance comes even as the bank expects growth in the face of these economic headwinds.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock saw initial volatility but ultimately gained on Wednesday despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook. This was influenced by anticipated interest rate cuts and slowing economic growth. The bank also reported a second-quarter profit that beat expectations, although net interest income was slightly below forecasts and sales and trading revenue declined significantly.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock gained Wednesday despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook, anticipating two Fed interest-rate cuts. The bank reported better-than-expected second-quarter profits but slightly shy net interest income and a 10% decline in sales and trading revenue. This decline includes an 8% drop in fixed income, currencies, and commodities revenue, marking its fourth consecutive quarterly decrease, and a 13% fall in equities revenue.

title: Bank of America’s stock seesaws to a gain after post-earnings conference call
summary: Bank of America's stock gained Wednesday despite the bank lowering its full-year net interest income outlook, anticipating two Fed interest-rate cuts. The bank reported a Q2 profit that beat expectations, although net interest income was slightly lower and sales and trading revenue fell 10%. This decline was driven by an 8% drop in fixed income, currencies, and commodities revenue (its fourth straight quarterly decline) and a 13% tumble in equities revenue.

title: Best Visa credit card in India: Types, features and benefits
summary: This article provides a comprehensive guide to Visa credit cards in India, outlining different card types such as Classic, Gold, Platinum, Signature, and Infinite, along with their respective features and benefits. It also explains how to obtain a Visa credit card, how the Visa network operates, and essential tips for secure usage. Additionally, the article lists several Indian banks offering Visa credit cards and highlights options with no annual fee.

title: Bank of America CFO warns that falling rates will hit net interest income
summary: Bank of America's CFO, Paul Donofrio, warned that the projected growth in net interest income for 2019 could fall from 3% to 1% due to anticipated interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. This potential reduction in NII is attributed to lower yields on floating rate assets, reduced coupons on new bonds, and mortgage refinancing at lower rates. Despite this, Bank of America shares rose after the bank posted record profits exceeding analysts' estimates.

title: BofA fined by S. Korea exchange over ‘almost phantom orders'
summary: Bank of America was fined by the South Korea exchange for alleged "almost phantom orders." The article's main focus is this regulatory action. The additional content includes other unrelated financial news snippets from the publication.

title: Second Quarter 2019 Results and Key Metrics
summary: Citigroup reported strong second-quarter 2019 results with net income of $4.8 billion ($1.95 per share) and revenues of $18.8 billion. The company returned $4.6 billion to shareholders and plans to return at least $60 billion in capital over three CCAR cycles, demonstrating disciplined expense management and growth across its consumer and institutional businesses.

title: BMV y Biva operan con ganancia de más de 1%; GMéxico cae por quinta sesión
summary: The Mexican Stock Exchange (BMV) and Biva are operating with gains over 1% early this Monday, with Financiero Banorte leading the advance and América Móvil also seeing increases. Conversely, Grupo México's shares have fallen for a fifth consecutive day following an acid spill in the Sea of Cortés, making it the biggest loser amongst the index components. The market is also anticipating upcoming quarterly reports from several companies.

title: Report: Bank of America's Cathy Bessant in talks for Wells Fargo CEO job - Bizwomen
summary: Cathy Bessant, Bank of America's chief operations and technology officer, is reportedly in talks for the Wells Fargo CEO position, according to a Bloomberg report. She joins a list of potential candidates, including industry figures from JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, and Bank of New York Mellon, to replace former CEO Tim Sloan who stepped down in March. The new CEO will face the challenge of addressing Wells Fargo's ongoing scandals stemming from improper business practices and a federal asset cap implemented in 2018.

title: SunTrust joins wave of banks cutting ties with private prison industry
summary: SunTrust announced it will no longer provide financing to companies managing private prisons or immigration holding facilities, joining a trend among major banks. This decision follows similar moves by JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America, driven by stakeholder views and increased scrutiny of the private prison industry. The timing of SunTrust's announcement is significant as the bank faces a House Financial Services Committee hearing regarding its proposed acquisition by BB&T.

title: Streaming Platform Douyu Updates US IPO Terms
summary: Douyu TV, the largest game-centric live streaming platform in China, has updated its US IPO terms. It plans to offer 67.4 million shares, including American Depository Shares (ADS) to be listed on Nasdaq under "DOYU" priced between $11.50 and $14.00. The company's expected valuation ranges from $3.73 billion to $4.54 billion.

title: Deutsche Bank outlines significant strategic transformation and restructuring plans
summary: Deutsche Bank announced a significant strategic transformation and restructuring plan aimed at improving long-term profitability. Key measures include exiting Global Equities, reducing Fixed Income operations, and creating a Capital Release Unit to wind down non-strategic assets. The bank also plans a cost reduction program, expects cumulative charges of EUR 7.4 billion by 2022, and will not pay common equity dividends for 2019 and 2020 to fund the transformation.

title: The Battle for Bankers After Brexit Is Heating Up
summary: Bank of America Corp. is actively recruiting traders from rival firms like Morgan Stanley and Credit Suisse Group AG for its new European hub in Paris. This move signifies a broader trend of financial institutions relocating trading operations from London to other European cities in response to Brexit, intensifying the competition for banking talent.

title: Bank of America Will Stop Lending to Private-Prison Firms
summary: Bank of America, the second-biggest U.S. bank, announced its decision to stop lending to companies that operate private prisons and detention centers. This move follows an internal due diligence process and discussions with civil rights leaders. JPMorgan and Wells Fargo had previously indicated they would also exit this business space.

title: The GEO Group Comments on Bank of America Decision and Expects No Impact on Recently Extended Senior Revolving Credit Facility
summary: The GEO Group responded to Bank of America's decision to cease financing correctional and rehabilitation services, stating it anticipates no impact on its recently extended Senior Revolving Credit Facility. CEO George C. Zoley clarified GEO's role, emphasizing that they do not manage facilities housing unaccompanied minors or border patrol holding facilities and that their Immigration and Customs Enforcement Processing Centers provide high-quality, humane residential care. The company highlighted its long-standing public-private partnership with the federal government and commitment to high standards.

title: Charlotte-based BofA rolls out digital debit card
summary: Bank of America is introducing a new digital debit card accessible through its mobile app, offering faster access to funds for customers awaiting a physical card. This initiative aims to improve customer convenience by providing immediate card functionality.

title: Dimon to Bank of America: We’re Coming for You in Branch-Expansion Battle
authors: Michelle F Davis and Lananh Nguyen
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. CEO Jamie Dimon has declared a competitive battle with Bank of America Corp., as both banks plan significant branch expansions across the U.S. Each bank aims to add at least 400 branches in new and existing markets over the coming years, with 90 new retail locations opened by each in 2019 alone. This strategic move intensifies competition for consumer deposits in rapidly growing U.S. cities.

title: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan on Why the U.S. Will Avoid a Recession
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan believes the U.S. economy will avoid a recession, expecting GDP growth to flatten out at 2%. He emphasizes the bank's "responsible growth" mantra, which includes direct consumer lending, tolerating market-share declines in mortgages for safer operations, and offering no-fee checking accounts with direct deposit. Moynihan's leadership has been praised for turning BofA around, increasing profitability and stock value, despite some past decisions.

title: Bank of Marin operations chief Jim Kimball resigns – The Press Democrat
summary: James S. Kimball resigned as executive vice president and chief operating officer of Bank of Marin, effective June 19, 2019. President and CEO Russell A. Colombo stated Kimball's departure was not part of a long-term plan and would not affect the bank's strategy, also praising Kimball's skills as a banker and leader. Kimball, 54, joined Bank of Marin in October 2017 after a long career including roles at Wells Fargo, Wachovia Bank, and Bank of America, with his 2018 compensation totaling $633,968.

title: Lloyds Bank Freezes Offshore Accounts in Money Laundering Crackdown
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc has frozen accounts of some offshore banking customers in Jersey as part of a crackdown on money laundering. The Financial Times reported that 8,000 accounts were frozen, though the bank did not confirm the exact number. This action is part of the bank's efforts to tighten controls and meet anti-money-laundering requirements on the island.

title: FOMC Recap Doves Play Catchup With Markets
summary: The Federal Reserve hinted at interest rate cuts, with nearly half of voting members now anticipating two cuts this year, largely due to ongoing trade disputes. Markets are pricing in a high probability of a cut in July, and potentially a second in September. This shift led to falling bond yields, a slight rise in equities, and significant moves in gold, USD/JPY, and USD/CHF.

title: SunPower, Hannon Armstrong and SunStrong Secure Attractive Financing for Residential Solar Lease Business Into 2020
summary: SunPower, Hannon Armstrong, and SunStrong Capital Holdings have secured financing commitments for SunPower's residential solar lease program, enabling them to meet customer demand into 2020. This new fund, structured as a levered tax equity partnership, supplements existing cash and loan purchase options. Additionally, SunStrong acquired a residential lease portfolio from Capital Dynamics, adding over 41 MW and 5,100 residential systems to its assets.

title: DOJ settles redlining lawsuit against First Merchants Bank
summary: The U.S. Department of Justice has settled a redlining lawsuit against First Merchants Bank, alleging discriminatory residential mortgage lending practices in Indianapolis-Marion County. The settlement requires the bank to take several corrective actions, including opening new branches in majority-Black census tracts, investing in a special subsidy fund of $1.12 million, and increasing advertising and outreach in underserved areas. This marks the second fair lending settlement under the Trump administration, notably without a civil money penalty.

title: Fifth Third Bank closing 44 Chicago-area branches
summary: Fifth Third Bank plans to close 44 branches in the Chicago area following its acquisition of MB Financial. The consolidation, set for July 9 or 10, will result in 190 remaining branches in the region and a "relatively small" number of job cuts. This move positions Fifth Third Bank close to Northern Trust in terms of Chicago-area banking market share, vying for fourth place.

title: A delicate balance (sheet)
summary: Nonbank lenders are increasingly dominating the mortgage market, particularly in South Florida, by offering quicker loan approvals than traditional banks. This trend, while filling a market void, raises concerns about liquidity issues for nonbanks during economic downturns, as they lack the capital reserves and government backing of traditional banks, potentially leaving the housing market vulnerable. Financial experts and former regulators express worry about the potential for widespread defaults and the impact on the housing market if these nonbanks face financial distress.

title: How this Charlotte executive is getting Bank of America ready for what's next
summary: Wyatt Smith, Bank of America's market executive for commercial banking in the Carolinas, discusses cybersecurity, growth markets, and other significant trends impacting the bank. This conversation comes as Bank of America (NYSE: BAC), headquartered in Charlotte, is experiencing some of its best financial results. The article highlights how a Charlotte executive is preparing Bank of America for future challenges and opportunities.

title: See you at the ‘Truist’: BB&T, which scrapped Susquehanna, Nat Penn names, picks new brand
summary: BB&T and SunTrust announced their merged entity will be named "Truist," combining "trust" with an "I." The new name will brand the sixth-largest bank in the U.S. with approximately $450 billion in assets, but it is facing skepticism from branding experts and the public. The merger is driven by the need for bank automation and technology, according to analyst Stephen Scouten, who currently rates the shares as "neutral."

title: BB&T, SunTrust announce merger to become Truist
summary: BB&T and SunTrust Banks announced their merger to form Truist, which will become the sixth-largest U.S. bank holding company, serving over 10 million households. The merger is expected to close in the third or fourth quarter of 2019, pending regulatory and shareholder approvals. Leadership roles in the new company have been outlined, with Kelly S. King becoming Chairman and CEO, and Bill Rogers becoming President and COO before succeeding King in 2021.

title: 'It's a free-for-all' PNC CEO says of big bank branch expansion
summary: PNC CEO William Demchak states that national retail expansion is a learning process, anticipating that newcomers Bank of America and Chase will take market share in Pittsburgh. He discussed this strategy at a Morgan Stanley conference, alongside related topics such as PNC's early childhood education program and comments about Wells Fargo.

title: Salesforce bets on big data with $15.3 billion Tableau buy
summary: Salesforce.com Inc announced its acquisition of big data firm Tableau Software Inc for $15.3 billion in an all-stock deal, marking its largest acquisition to date. This move aims to enhance Salesforce's data insights offerings to clients and follows a trend of tech giants investing in big data analytics. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter, with Tableau operating independently, but will impact Salesforce's 2020 adjusted profit despite adding to revenue.

title: Fidelity custody business hooks up with lender to finance RIAs
summary: Fidelity Clearing & Custody Solutions has partnered with Merchant Investment Management to provide its RIA clients with preferential access to business loans for acquisitions and succession planning. This alliance aims to offer RIAs a capital alternative without requiring them to give up equity, with a discounted loan origination fee for Fidelity's clients. The move is designed to help RIAs access the capital needed for growth and scale through M&A.

title: Millennial Online Fashion Retailer Revolve Trending in Wall Street Debut
summary: Millennial-focused online fashion retailer Revolve Group Inc. saw its stock jump dramatically in its trading debut on the New York Stock Exchange, valuing the company at about $1.8 billion after raising $212 million in its IPO. The company, which leverages Instagram and influencers for marketing, reported profitability with $31 million in earnings on $499 million in sales last year. Revolve aims to use the IPO proceeds for stock buybacks and continued growth, despite potential international expansion challenges and tariff risks.

title: BBVA Banco Francés y el Santander Río cambian de nombre
summary: BBVA Banco Francés and Santander Río are changing their names to BBVA Argentina and Banco Santander, respectively, as part of a global rebranding strategy focused on digital transformation. This change will see two long-standing financial brands in Argentina disappear, with the new names being presented to the public at the Martín Fierro awards ceremony. The move aims to enhance digital credibility, create global synergies, and facilitate expansion into new markets.

title: Banking veteran promoted to prominent new role
summary: Cadence Bank has promoted Teresa Stinson to executive vice president of its Florida commercial banking operations. Stinson succeeds John Watts, who died unexpectedly in April, and brings over 32 years of banking experience to the role. Cadence Bank CEO Sam Tortorici expressed confidence in Stinson's leadership for continued growth in Florida.

title: Santander pays US$50mn to end São Paulo tax probe
summary: Santander's Brazilian unit agreed to pay 196mn reais (US$49.7mn) to settle a tax evasion investigation in São Paulo. The probe focused on allegations that banks' leasing and factoring companies registered headquarters in other cities for tax benefits. Santander made the payment without admitting guilt, closing the case after a court ordered its CEO to attend a commission hearing.

title: BofA Jumps on Tap-to-Pay Bandwagon as NYC’s Subway Moves Forward
summary: Bank of America (BAC) is joining other financial institutions in issuing tap-to-pay cards, starting with 4 million contactless Visa debit or credit cards this month to customers in New York, Boston, and San Francisco. This move aligns with the increasing adoption of contactless payments, notably as New York City's subway system moves forward with tap-to-pay options. The bank plans to evaluate usage in these initial markets before a broader rollout next year.

title: Synovus picks Regions exec as new CFO
summary: Synovus has named Jamie Gregory, formerly of Regions, as its new executive vice president and CFO. This appointment follows the previous CFO, Kevin Blair, being named COO in late 2018.

title: Online Pet Food Company Looking To IPO At $7 Billion In 2019 Because We've All Learned Literally Nothing
summary: Chewy.com, an online pet food company, is planning an IPO with a proposed valuation of $7 billion despite not being profitable and having lost $268 million last year. The IPO involves a dual share structure that will allow PetSmart, the current majority owner, to maintain control. This move is drawing comparisons to the dot-com bubble's Pet.com.

title: US Bank sues BofA for mortgage-related breach of contract
summary: U.S. Bancorp has filed a lawsuit against Bank of America Corp., alleging a breach of contract related to mortgage-backed securities. This legal action targets BofA, which has its corporate headquarters in Charlotte. The article mentions related past legal challenges faced by Bank of America, including trademark lawsuits and discrimination claims.

title: Global Payments is nearing an agreement to acquire Total System Services for roughly $20 billion in latest fintech deal
summary: Global Payments is nearing an all-stock deal to acquire Total System Services (TSYS) for approximately $20 billion, marking the latest consolidation in the payment technology sector. The deal is expected to be announced on Tuesday and follows other major fintech acquisitions earlier in the year. Both companies have been active acquirers, seeking to expand their technology and customer bases amidst increasing competition from new tech players.

title: Exclusive: JPMorgan cuts ties with OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma - sources
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has cut ties with Purdue Pharma LP due to the OxyContin maker's alleged role in the U.S. opioid crisis, forcing Purdue to find a new bank to manage cash and bill payments. This move makes JPMorgan the most high-profile corporation to distance itself from Purdue and the Sackler family amidst thousands of lawsuits. Purdue has since tapped Comerica Inc to handle its financial transactions and accounts.

title: Tesla shares could drop to $10 in a worst-case scenario, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley cut its worst-case forecast for Tesla stock from $97 to $10, citing concerns over the company's debt load and geopolitical exposure, particularly regarding Chinese demand. Despite this, the firm maintained its main price target of $230 and a bull-case forecast of $391, suggesting Tesla's strategic value remains high. Other firms like Baird also lowered their estimates, while T. Rowe Price significantly reduced its holdings, reflecting broader investor concerns amidst Tesla's recent poor quarterly performance and stock decline.

title: Meridian Bank delays 1Q earnings report due to mortgage snafu
summary: Meridian Bank has delayed its first-quarter earnings report because it originated residential mortgage loans in a neighboring state where it was not licensed. The bank disclosed that this oversight would result in a material weakness.

title: The Good, The Bad, & The Ugly Of US Mobile Banking Experiences In 2019
summary: Forrester's 2019 review of US mobile banking apps found that while banks excel at log-in and money movement features, they are only "just OK" at self-service and financial management. A significant weakness identified was their failure to provide actionable financial advice and adequately reassure users on security and privacy. The report highlights Bank of America and USAA as leading providers in money management and service features.

title: 20s Maurice Goodman
authors: John R. Boehm and Stephen J. Serio
summary: Maurice Goodman, 27, is a risk and settlement manager at Seed CX, a cryptocurrency trading platform, where he helps attract clients and manages risk. Before joining Seed CX, he honed his skills at CME Group and Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Goodman is also an active real estate investor, co-founding Goodman & Przybyl Properties, and is inspired by his parents' hard work and entrepreneurial spirit.

title: Bank of America names new San Antonio market president
summary: Jessica Miller has been appointed as Bank of America Corp.'s new San Antonio market president. This announcement comes as Bank of America was ranked third in June 2018 among banks with branches in San Antonio, based on local deposits.

title: Tesla may be about to lose a key group of investors that have stuck with the struggling stock
summary: Tesla's recent pivot towards autonomous driving, highlighted by CEO Elon Musk's statements during an investor call, may alienate long-term growth investors who anticipated profitability from high-volume auto sales. While a recent $2.7 billion stock and bond offering provided a temporary relief rally, Barclays analyst Brian Johnson suggests the focus on autonomy pushes out the timeline for investor payoff, potentially causing "rational bulls" to reassess their investment in the struggling stock.

title: Buffett Says Bank of America CEO Was Matchmaker on Occidental Deal
summary: Warren Buffett revealed that Bank of America Corp. CEO Brian Moynihan played a crucial role in initiating his $10 billion investment in Occidental Petroleum Corp. Moynihan called Buffett to inform him that his bank was involved in financing the Occidental deal and that Occidental's representatives wished to speak with him. This phone call led to Buffett's significant investment in the oil company.

title: Tesla raises $2.35 billion in boosted debt and stock offerings
summary: Tesla Inc. successfully raised $2.35 billion through boosted debt and stock offerings, exceeding initial plans and alleviating near-term liquidity concerns. The capital raise, which included $750 million in common stock and $1.6 billion in convertible bonds, sparked a relief rally for the company's stock and bonds. This funding will help Tesla repay debt, finance Model 3 shipments to Europe, and cover potential cash burn from softening demand, as the company invests in new vehicles and a factory in Shanghai.

title: Elon Musk owes $507 million to banks helping Tesla raise capital
summary: Elon Musk personally owes $507 million to Wall Street banks involved in Tesla's recent stock and debt sale, a figure backed by his significant stake in the electric car maker. This amount is lower than the $624 million disclosed in 2017, with Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Bank of America being the primary lenders. The article highlights potential conflicts of interest for these banks and the risk of Musk being forced to sell shares if Tesla's stock price declines further.

title: Bank of Morgan Stanley?
summary: Morgan Stanley's CEO James Gorman has restructured the leadership of its wealth management and institutional banking units, leading to speculation that the firm is aiming to expand into a full-service bank. This move, which includes Shelley O’Connor overseeing both banking parts of the business, suggests a future where Morgan Stanley might resemble Bank of America or JPMorgan. The article highlights that Morgan Stanley has already shifted significantly in the past decade, with half its revenues coming from wealth management.
